Project Title: Development and Implementation of the REmote Telehealth User-Reported caNcer Surveillance (RETURNS) Program for Lung Cancer
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEAlthough lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer-related death in the United States over 540000Americans survive with treatment making it the fourth leading diagnosis among cancer survivors a 20%increase in 2022. Lung cancer surveillance plays an important role in survivorship care through the detectionof both recurrent disease and new `second primary' lung cancer monitoring of toxicity associated withadjuvant treatment reinforcement of smoking cessation and management of fear and anxiety over potentialrecurrence; yet only 26% of patients receive the guideline-recommended imaging and 39% are lost to allfollow-up after lung cancer resection. This proposal seeks to leverage RETURNS a telehealth lung cancersurveillance program to develop and test a remote lung cancer surveillance approach combining PatientReported Outcome (PRO) and community chest computed tomography (CT) assessment in a learning healthsystem to improve adherence to recommended surveillance guidelines by reducing barriers and making caremore efficient and effective for patients providers and the healthcare system.
Organization Name: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR

Project Title: Wake Forest NCORP Research Base
Public Health Relevance: The Wake Forest NCORP Research Base develops and implements multi-site Cancer Control and Cancer CareDelivery (CCDR) clinical research studies in partnership with NCORP Community and Minority/UnderservedCommunity Sites to improve patient well-being and the quality of cancer care.
Other PI or Project Leader(s): DRESSLER, EMILY VAN METER; WEAVER, KATHRYN ELIZABETH

Project Title: Diverse effects of hemin on the endothelium contribute to pulmonary complications of sickle cell disease
Public Health Relevance: Pulmonary complications are the most common cause of death in patients with sickle cell disease and arethought to be caused by the release of toxins during the breakdown of red blood cells. This proposal expandson our previous work to identify the role of hemin a toxin released during breakdown of red blood cells in thedevelopment of these pulmonary complications namely pulmonary hypertension and acute chest syndrome.We use preclinical models as well as genomic data from sickle cell disease patients to better understand thesedeadly complications in order to develop new therapies.
Study Section: Respiratory Integrative Biology and Translational Research Study Section[RIBT]

Project Title: Social Media Action to Reach Teach and Educate Greater Richmond VA 2.0 (SMARTER-VA 2.0)
Public Health Relevance: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe mission of the Massey Cancer Center (MCC) is to reduce the state cancer burden for all Virginians byaddressing the confluence between biological social and policy drivers through high-impact cutting-edgeresearch; person-centered care across the continuum from prevention through survivorship; communityintegration; and training the next generation of community-centric researchers and healthcare professionals. Thecore of this mission has been supported by the National Cancer Institutes Cancer Center Support Grant (CCSG)since 1975 and the MCC is seeking renewal of this award for another five years. The CCSG supports effortsacross the MCC senior and programmatic leadership; administration; community outreach and engagement;cancer research training and education coordination; promotion of center-wide diversity equity and inclusion;shared resource support and management; clinical research infrastructure; and developmental funding tosupporting team-based transdisciplinary research strategies focused on well-defined catchment area priorities.

Project Title: Mayo CCCG (Supp) - Impact of Multi-Channel Communication Campaigns on Cancer Prevention Control and Survivorship (CaPCaS) in Black Hispanic Rural and Sexual and Gender Minority Populations
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis application is being submitted by the Mayo Clinic Comprehensive Cancer Center (MCCCC) in response tothe request for an extension of the Administrative Supplements for the NCI P30 Cancer Center Support Grantsfor Multi-Channel Communication Campaigns. The primary goal of the extension will continue efforts for theimplementation sustainability and evaluation of the MICEO initiatives across the MCCCC enterprisefocusing on: Black men (prostate cancer) Hispanic adults (colorectal and liver cancers) rural-residing adults(lung and colorectal cancers) and expansion to include Sexual and Gender Minority health. This extension willenable us to further our assessment of the impact of multi-channel communication campaigns targeting BlackHispanic Rural and sexual and gender minority populations on cancer prevention control and survivorship(CaPCaS).

Project Title: TRAINING NAVIGATOR CCSG SUPPLEMENT
Public Health Relevance: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe mission of the Massey Cancer Center (MCC) is to reduce the state cancer burden for all Virginians byaddressing the confluence between biological social and policy drivers through high-impact cutting-edgeresearch; person-centered care across the continuum from prevention through survivorship; communityintegration; and training the next generation of community-centric researchers and healthcare professionals. Thecore of this mission has been supported by the National Cancer Institutes Cancer Center Support Grant (CCSG)since 1975 and the MCC is seeking renewal of this award for another five years. The CCSG supports effortsacross the MCC senior and programmatic leadership; administration; community outreach and engagement;cancer research training and education coordination; promotion of center-wide diversity equity and inclusion;shared resource support and management; clinical research infrastructure; and developmental funding tosupporting team-based transdisciplinary research strategies focused on well-defined catchment area priorities.

Project Title: Disparities in breast cancer treatment using Granulocyte colony-stimulating factors and CDK4/6 inhibitors between African and European ancestry individuals in two large Electronic Health Records
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALLThe well-established Meharry Medical College/Vanderbilt-Ingram Cancer Center/Tennessee State UniversityCancer Partnership (MVTCP) triad provides an exceptional environment to identify and address health careinequities in cancer seen in underrepresented minorities. The proposed research projects cores and sharedresource cores will grow research and propose evidence-based solutions address to these inequities. Furtherthe development of expanded research infrastructure at MMC and TSU enhancement of minority educationprograms and improvement to the effectiveness of cancer-related activities will address health care disparitiesin the greater Nashville geographical region with the ultimate goal of contributing to reducing health disparitiesamong cancer patients in minority and underserved communities.

Project Title: Returning to Everyday Tasks Utilizing Rehabilitation Networks-III Pilot Randomized Clinical Trial (RETURN-III Pilot RCT)
Public Health Relevance: Millions of patients survive care in medical and surgical Intensive Care Units (ICUs) every year onlyto suffer from a new or accelerated dementia-like process called post-ICU long-term cognitiveimpairment (ICU-LTCI). ICU-LTCI causes considerable problems with personal relationships returnto work and everyday tasks such as managing medicines and money. No treatment for thesepatients is currently available. Technology using computerized cognitive rehabilitation could improveICU-LTCI by harnessing the healing potential of the brain (i.e. neuroplasticity). This intervention isscalable portable and economical. We will evaluate the effectiveness of computerized cognitiverehabilitation in a randomized controlled trial of 160 VA patients with ICU-LTCI. We hypothesize thatthis intervention could improve cognition and brain structure shown by MRI. This research has highpotential to influence rehabilitation strategies for Veteran and civilian ICU survivors.

Project Title: Sympathetic modulation of head and neck cancer pain
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEHead and neck cancer patients experience severe pain and stress. The proposed studies investigate howsympathetic and sensory nerves interact to drive cancer pain and promote cancer growth. This approach hasthe potential for new therapeutic strategies to treat cancer progression and pain by targeting neurons.
Study Section: Neurobiology of Pain and Itch Study Section [NPI]

Project Title: Assessing and Enhancing Survivorship Care In Rural and Urban Patients with Head and Neck Cancer
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis project is relevant to public health by identifying opportunities to tailor cancer survivorship care programs'policies processes and evaluation/assessment metrics to meet the needs of patients with head and neck cancerliving in urban and rural settings. Thus this project aligns with the National Cancer Institute's mission byadvancing scientific knowledge in cancer survivorship and helping all people live longer healthier lives.
Organization Name: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON

Project Title: Applying National Standards to Evaluate Cancer Survivorship Care Quality: A Mixed Methods Study
Public Health Relevance: Project Narrative:The proposed project examines the extent to which the Buffet Cancer Center Survivorship Programaligns with recently developed National Standards for Survivorship Care by evaluating the organizationalpolicies and processes for delivering survivorship care. Document reviews and interviews will be conducted toassess the alignment of current policies and procedures with the National Standards as well as EHR analysesto determine survivorship program utilization and examine referral rates and the number of survivors lostto follow-up across cancer types. Using the National Standards for Survivorship Care as a guidingframework this study seeks to inform policy practice and future research efforts aimed at improving the long-term care and outcomes of cancer survivors in the United States.

Project Title: P30 Administrative Supplement for Assessing and Enhancing Survivorship Care
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis project aims to utilize group model building with clinicians patients and families to developthe first qualitative model of childhood cancer survivorship care. The model will identify andanalyze barriers within the care process to improve accessibility and adherence to guidelines innon-specialized clinics. The outcomes will identify optimal targets for improving survivorship carethereby enhancing health equity and improving care delivery for the growing survivor population.

Project Title: Stanford Cancer Institute
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeThe long term-goal of the proposed study is to develop effective strategies to ensure that cancer survivors haveaccess to guideline concordant care and timely referrals to supportive services at Stanford Medicine. The projectwill evaluate Stanfords alignment with recently issued National Standards for Cancer Survivorship Care identifygaps and barriers to effective care delivery and provide data and insights to inform survivorship careimplementation resource allocation and training of professionals to deliver quality survivorship care.

Project Title: Improving Survivorship Care for Adolescents and Young Adults: a Mixed Methods Study of Alignment with the National Standards for Survivorship Care
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis proposal aims to investigate the level of alignment between the survivorship services provided by acomprehensive cancer center and the National Standards for Survivorship Care. Additionally it will analyze theutilization rates of the Survivorship Clinic among a sample of adolescent and young adult cancer survivors whowere initially eligible to take part in a randomized trial involving a mobile app and website designed to reducedistress and enhance adherence to healthcare in the parent grant. Lastly qualitative interviews will beconducted with a subset of AYA participants to explore their experiences and the barriers and facilitators theyencountered in accessing survivorship-focused care.

Project Title: Administrative Supplement for Assessing and Enhancing Survivorship Care
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe Atrium Health Wake Forest Baptist Comprehensive Cancer Center (AHWFBCCC) catchment areaincludes 4.8 million residents about one-third racial/ethnic minority and a significant rural footprint. Theproposed work will evaluate the extent to which survivorship care programs in this multidimensional health caresystem align with recently developed National Standards for Survivorship Care through a mixed-methodsaction planning process that considers different contexts in depth and will inform future implementation ofoptimized survivorship care. Establishing a systematic process for assessing and improving accessiblesurvivorship care with a balance of common unified services and variations tailored to local demands willposition AHWFBCCC to contribute to a broader understanding of what survivorship care models are optimallyeffective in diverse populations.

Project Title: Administrative Supplement: Assessing and Enhancing Survivorship Care
Public Health Relevance: EXPOSURE: Project NarrativeAlthough engagement in long-term follow-up survivor care is critical to the lifelong health of the growingchildhood cancer survivor (CCS) population >25% of CCS are not accessing survivor care nationally.Understanding the factors impacting the landscape of pediatric survivor care (e.g. institutional uptake ofstandards population reach patient engagement) may reduce gaps in care delivery for CCS. The objectives ofthis supplement to the Winship Cancer Institute's NCI-designated P30 Cancer Center grant are to examine: 1)the alignment of the care offered to pediatric CCS with the National Standards for Survivorship Care 2) thelong-term utilization of pediatric survivor services and 3) patient- and family-level factors related to long-termengagement in survivor care.

Project Title: Cancer Center Support Grant - Gunn Supplement
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeEven after completing cancer treatment cancer survivors have increased health risks compared with thegeneral population necessitating ongoing care through survivorship programs. This project will assessDartmouth Cancer Centers survivorship services against a new set of national standards for survivorshipprograms to identify areas where Dartmouth Cancer Centers program can be enhanced to meet ruralsurvivors needs and engage them in care through digital tools and other innovative solutions. The project willproduce a set of recommendations for quality improvement initiatives to support lasting impacts on survivorshipcare delivery and outcomes for survivors in rural areas.

Project Title: Assessing Markey Cancer Center's Alignment with National Standards for Survivorship Care
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVE Markey Cancer Center is the only NCI-designated Comprehensive Cancer Center in the state ofKentucky and its catchment area includes all 120 counties in Kentucky. The mission of Markey CancerCenter is to reduce cancer burden which necessitates translating scientific discoveries into innovativepersonalized care and providing the highest quality care to cancer survivors. This administrative supplementaims to assess alignment between survivorship care at Markey Cancer Center and the National Standardsfor Cancer Survivorship Care identify determinants of survivorship care access for survivors and theircaregivers and identify implementation strategies to improve quality effectiveness adoption and reach ofsurvivorship care at Markey.

Project Title: Social Health Activity Behaviors and Quality of Life among Young Adult Cancer Survivors: A longitudinal Study Administrative Supplement
Public Health Relevance: NarrativeAccess to and receipt of high-quality survivorship care is of paramount importance for survivors of young adult(YA) cancers who experience long-term risks across multiple health domains and have many life-years to live.This supplement will assess alignment between the new National Standards for Survivorship Care and asurvivorship care program that serves diverse YAs; access to and utilization of survivorship care amongdiverse YAs; and identify multi-level gaps for future development. Findings of this study will illuminateopportunity areas for YA cancer survivorship care delivery in alignment with the new National Standards andthereby inform efforts to develop and implement high-quality survivorship programs that serve and engagediverse YA survivors.

Project Title: Assessing and Enhancing Survivorship Care in Adolescent and Young Adult Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeDespite the availability of guidelines for cancer survivorship including the newly released National Standardsfor Cancer Survivorship Care receipt and overall quality of survivorship care is inconsistent across survivorsand treating facilities with gaps in our knowledge of best practices for delivering tailored survivorship care tomeet the unique needs of adolescent and young adult (AYAs) cancer survivors. Within this proposal our teamwill conduct a mixed-methods study of AYA cancer survivors (ages 15-39 years at diagnosis) diagnosedbetween 2014-2019 using cancer registry data linked with electronic health record (EHR) data and patientsurveys and supplemented by focus groups and key informant interviews with stakeholders. Our primary goalis to understand the current landscape of how national survivorship care standards are implemented to identifybarriers driving underutilization of AYA survivorship care and to develop priorities for enhanced survivorshipcare that directly address patient-driven approaches for reducing these barriers.

Project Title: Bright IDEAS-Young Adults: Problem-Solving Skills Training to Reduce Distress among Young Adults with Cancer
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeThe delivery of survivorship care for young adults (ages 18-39) with cancer is often fragmented and poorlycoordinated resulting in suboptimal care and leaving these young adult survivors with persistent unmet needs.This supplement will leverage a fully enrolled clinical trial evaluating a psychosocial intervention to improvequality of life outcomes for young adults with cancer to examine how early survivorship care aligns with theNational Standards for Cancer Survivorship Care and identify barriers and facilitators to obtaining high-qualitycare. Results will inform future interventions tailored to the needs of young adults with cancer to enhancesurvivorship care and quality of life outcomes.

Project Title: Clinical Care Gaps and Unmet Needs in Adolescent and Young Adult (AYA) Cancers
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeThere is an urgent need to provide high-quality survivorship care to the rapidly growing population ofadolescent and young adult (AYA) cancer survivors. The new National Standards for Cancer Survivorship Careprovide a robust framework for developing and assessing survivorship care programs across and within U.S.healthcare systems. We will leverage our existing large contemporary cohort of AYA cancer survivors cared forwithin Kaiser Permanente to: 1) Examine the availability of the new National Standards within KP; 2) Assessreferral to and utilization of recommended National Standards within our KP AYA cancer survivor cohort; theproposed work will be a supplement to our current program grant (P01CA233432).

Project Title: CCSG Supplement: Assessing Facilitators and Barriers to Implementation of the National Survivorship Care Standards in Rural Health Systems
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVEThere are more than 18 million cancer survivors in the U.S. approximately 20% of which live inrural communities. This study will assess facilitators and barriers to implementing the NationalStandards for Cancer Survivorship Care in rural health systems. The findings will informeducation and outreach efforts in the Consortium Catchment area as well as future research topromote implementation of high-quality accessible survivorship care in rural health systemsnationally.

Project Title: Designing for sustainability: Co-designing and testing the efficacy of a web-based toolkit to improve cancer-related emotional distress and anxiety for rural older cancer survivors
Public Health Relevance: Project Narrative:Responding to the pressing need to enhance digital literacy as a means to improve access to healthcareresources for rural populations and in alignment with NINRs call for Strategies to Improve Health Outcomesand Advance Health Equity in Rural Populations (RFA-NR-24-005) we developed CONNECT a web-basedtool designed to enhance digital literacy and access to cancer-related emotional distress and anxiety resourcesfor rural older cancer survivors (ROCS). Building upon the positive feedback from our usability pilot and theDesigning for Dissemination logic model the proposed study seeks to adapt CONNECT to include functionsrecommended from our usability pilot and assess its efficacy and implementation in improving levels of cancer-related distress and digital engagement for ROCS compared to an enhanced standard care arm in a 12-monthRCT. Successful completion of our aims will yield: 1) multi-level strategies enhancing healthcare delivery andaccess fostering health equity in rural populations by improving digital literacy; 2) design strategies supportingthe potential sustainability of digital tool development for marginalized populations; and 3) pertinent data tofacilitate the scaled implementation of CONNECT in a future implementation-effectiveness hybrid trial.

Project Title: Cancer Center Support Grant (CCSG)
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe five multidisciplinary research Programs and nine Shared Resources in the SJCCC work together to findcures for pediatric cancer while minimizing the long-term side effects of treatment. With strong institutionaland philanthropic support for 56 years we have served as a national and international resource for health careproviders children with cancer and their families.

Project Title: Enhance the CCSS biospecimen resource through characterization of clonal hematopoiesis among survivors of childhood cancer
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVESurvival rates for many childhood and adolescent cancers have improved at a remarkable pace over the pastfive decades. The Childhood Cancer Survivor Study (CCSS; U24 CA055727; PI: Armstrong) cohort has beenthe source of some of the most significant publications to date addressing the long-term mortality morbidity andquality of life of survivors of childhood cancer. Understanding the risk for late effects of childhood cancer and itstherapy provides the basis for health screening recommendations and interventions that can mitigate long-termhealth problems in this high-risk population.

Project Title: Targeting the Tumor Microenvironment in Patients with AIDS-Associated EBV+ Diffuse Large B Cell Lymphoma
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe Ohio State University Comprehensive Cancer Center (OSUCCC) is a matrix cancer center that integratesand leverages all of the resources of the University to achieve its broad vision of creating a cancer free world.The OSUCCC addresses the public health needs of the catchment area (the state of Ohio) through researcheducation and community outreach and engagement as research conducted within the five OSUCCC Programsfocuses on high priority cancers for the OSUCCC including lung breast colorectal prostate endometrialcervical cancer thyroid and leukemia as well as tobacco use obesity and HPV vaccination. Screening andoutreach activities are provided to the populations across the lifespan that we serve especially those with higherburden of being diagnosed with cancer such as racial/ethnic minorities and other underserved populations (e.g.rural LGBTQ+ Appalachian) through targeted culturally appropriate education activities free cancerscreenings patient navigation community networking environmental scans and addressing policy issues.

Project Title: Using a SMART design to evaluate remotely delivered culturally tailored weight loss interventions among Latina breast cancer survivors
Public Health Relevance: PARENT PROJECT: PROJECT NARRATIVECancer is the leading cause of death among Latinos and among Latinas breast cancer is the leading cause ofcancer death. Latinas are a population at high risk of obesity diabetes and other cardiometaboliccomorbidities which are associated with poorer breast cancer outcomes. We will test adaptive interventions toidentify the most effective multi-component home-based online culturally-tailored weight loss adaptiveintervention in Latina breast cancer survivors.
Study Section: Lifestyle Change and Behavioral Health Study Section[LCBH]

Project Title: Transdisciplinary Team Science in Colorectal Cancer Prognosis: the ColoCare Study
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe ColoCare Study is a cohort of recently diagnosed patients with colorectal cancer (stage I-IV) that utilizesstandardized protocols for longitudinally collecting participant questionnaires biospecimens medical recorddata and clinical and patient-reported outcomes. Over 3000 demographically and geographically diverseparticipants have been recruited (with a median follow-up time of 2.1 years contributing >8000 questionnairesand >17000 biospecimens) and ColoCare data and/or biospecimens have supported 79 projects involving 72external investigators (19 projects led by external investigators and 49 from early stage investigators andtrainees). In this renewal we will extend follow-up through 5 years post-diagnosis; prioritize recruitment ofpatients from underserved/understudied populations and with early-onset colorectal cancer; continue repeatascertainment of self-reported data (including patient-reported outcomes) and blood samples; and enhance ourcentralized data repository and biobank to support data sharing and research that will improve colorectalcancer treatment survivorship and clinical outcomes.Project Narrative Page 9
Other PI or Project Leader(s): FIGUEIREDO, JANE C.; GIGIC, BILJANA ; SHIBATA, DAVID ; SIEGEL, ERIN ; TORIOLA, ADETUNJI T

Project Title: Peer-Led Support Intervention for Black Breast Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVECompared to non-Hispanic White women Black women have a 41% higher mortality rate and experienceworse psychosocial outcomes including greater psychological distress and lower health related quality of life(HRQOL). Aligned with the NINRs research lenses of health equity and social determinants of health theproposed study will examine the feasibility acceptability and preliminary efficacy of a collaboratively anditeratively designed and refined peer-led support intervention to reduce psychological distress and improveHRQOL among Black breast cancer survivors. Findings will lay the groundwork to test the interventionsefficacy in a fully powered randomized controlled trial (RCT).

Project Title: Explaining the potential role of physical activity in employment disparities after breast cancer
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEBreast cancer survivors are the largest group of cancer survivors and are at high risk for unemploymentespecially health disparity populations leading to financial toxicity and poor health outcomes. Despite thenumerous benefits of employment for cancer survivors cancer-related fatigue and cognitive impairment arecommon barriers to working; these barriers can be alleviated with physical activity but discrimination andaccessibility to exercise opportunities often experienced by Black cancer survivors living in the rural south canadversely impact these outcomes. This study proposes an innovative approach to explore the relationshipbetween physical activity and work disparities and the impact of fatigue cognitive limitations discriminationand accessibility to exercise opportunities and gain preliminary information to develop a future interventiontargeting physical activity and work-life barriers in breast cancer survivors at risk of unemployment andphysical inactivity.
Organization Name: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS

Project Title: Cancer Center Support Grant (CCSG)
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe five multidisciplinary research Programs and nine Shared Resources in the SJCCC work together to findcures for pediatric cancer while minimizing the long-term side effects of treatment. With strong institutionaland philanthropic support for 56 years we have served as a national and international resource for health careproviders children with cancer and their families.

Project Title: The Lymphoma Epidemiology of Outcomes (LEO) Cohort Study (Diversity Supplement - Mazie Tsang)
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVENHL is the most common hematologic malignancy and there are many unmet clinical and public health needsof this growing patient population. The goal of this infrastructure grant is to support a cohort of over 16000non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) patients in order to address broad and cutting-edge research that identifiesclinical epidemiologic (including lifestyle and other exposures) host genetic tumor and treatment factors andthe interaction among these factors on short and long-term outcomes. The efforts of this Supplement are wellaligned with the ultimate goal of identifying new approaches to improve the survival and well-being of NHLpatients.

Project Title: Adapting Survivorship Care to Rural Practice Translating Rural Evidence into Policy
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVEDeveloping engagement and policy translation skills of the next generation of rural cancer researchers willprove critical as many rural states experience rising cancer incidence amidst growing prevalence of cancersurvivors. Greater access to comprehensive survivorship services could mitigate the growing mortality disparitybetween rural-urban cancer patients but rural cancer centers need additional support to deliver such carelocally. Leveraging the resources of an innovative cancer center network intervention we propose toimplement an evidence-based survivorship workshop adapted to fit the unique needs of rural communities andexplore innovative approaches to disseminate our cancer equity research to rural policymakers.

Project Title: Analyzing the long-term effects of DNA methylation meditated immunosuppression following sepsis
Public Health Relevance: No Change from Original Project NarrativeProject NarrativeSeptic survivors exhibit long-term immunologic dysfunction associated with higher rates of disability depressionsubsequent infections and all-cause mortalities; however our understanding of the regulation of theseresponses and their impact on disease is lacking. This proposal will integrate mechanistic in vivo studies withhuman data and quality of life outcomes measures to provide an in-depth assessment of the systemicepigenetic events that occur during sepsis and how their regulation of the post-septic immunosuppressiveresponse effects the immunologic and functional outcomes of patients. The proposal has the potential toprovide fundamental insight into disease regulation and novel therapeutics for the treatment of post-sepsisimmunosuppression.

Project Title: An INteractive Survivorship Program to Improve Healthcare REsources [INSPIRE] for Adolescent and Young Adult (AYA) Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEAdolescent and young adult (AYA) cancer survivors live with emotional distress and health care demands thatexceed those of their peers but can have difficulty accessing the care they need. In a 5-site national studythis research will adapt a tested personalized interactive digital and telehealth survivorship program to theneeds of AYA survivors. We will test the AYA-focused survivorship intervention in a randomized controlled trialto see if it improves emotional distress and adherence to health care guidelines after 3 and 12 months whencompared to AYA survivors who receive access to a website of annotated links to existing survivorshipresources followed by delayed access to the digital survivorship program after 12 months.

Project Title: Sympathetic modulation of head and neck cancer pain
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEHead and neck cancer patients experience severe pain and stress. The proposed studies investigate howsympathetic and sensory nerves interact to drive cancer pain and promote cancer growth. This approach hasthe potential for new therapeutic strategies to treat cancer progression and pain by targeting neurons.
Study Section: Neurobiology of Pain and Itch Study Section [NPI]

Project Title: Physiological Behavioral and Predictive Correlates of Ototoxicity in Humans
Public Health Relevance: Chemotherapy medications can cause tinnitus hearing loss and communication deficits  known as ototoxicity in up to half of Veterans receiving these drugs. Predicting which patients will experience ototoxicity is currentlyimpossible. This is problematic because patients and their doctors generally lack awareness of earlyindicators of ototoxicity which could prompt intervention to address the subsequent health-related andpsychosocial consequences. By examining the auditory injury and the burden of morbidity from ototoxic agentsin relation to the perspectives of the patient-oncology team the proposed research will provide a betterunderstanding of which patients are at high risk for ototoxicity why they are more susceptible to the damageand how best to address their ototoxicity through monitoring rehabilitation and drug therapy interventions. Tofurther enhance patient-centered oncologic care this new knowledge will be used to develop tools forforecasting an individual patient's risk for ototoxicity using information obtained prior to treatment.

Project Title: ConnectedNest: a digital platform connecting individuals with cancer to social care
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVEConnectedNest developed by XanthosHealth using SBIR Phase I funding from NIH addresses the criticalissue of social determinants of health (SDoH) affecting individuals facing cancer aiming to reduce healthinequities and adverse outcomes. Through a pilot study in Minneapolis the platform demonstrated successfulengagement with community-based organizations (CBOs) and cancer survivors. In Phase II the project aimsto enhance ConnectedNest's technical features and conduct a randomized clinical trial recruiting patients frommultiple oncology clinics to evaluate its impact on patient health outcomes with the ultimate goal of providingan innovative cost-effective and scalable solution to connect individuals with essential social and communityservices in the context of cancer care and beyond.

Project Title: National Cancer Institute (NCI) Early Career Cancer Clinical Investigator Award (ECIA) P30 Administrative Supplement
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVERadiotherapy is routinely employed in the treatment of cancer and can cause a myriad of toxicities that maysignificantly affect quality of life during and after treatment. Through rigorous clinical research I aim to optimizethe therapeutic index of cancer treatment by maximizing the effectiveness of treatment minimizing the toxiceffects of radiotherapy understanding treatment toxicity and its effect on short- and long-term quality of life anddeveloping cancer control and symptom-directed risk mitigation strategies. The proposed research and careerdevelopment activities outlined in this application will propel me on the path of becoming an independent clinicalinvestigator and ensure that I am successful in advancing cancer clinical research at my institution and withinmultiple NCI-supported research groups.

Project Title: ADEPT-ICU: Attenuating Depression with Internet Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) to Slow Cognitive Decline in Older Intensive Care Unit (ICU) Survivors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEDepression affects one-third of intensive care unit (ICU) survivors and represents a potentially modifiabletarget to slow cognitive decline and reduce the risk of Alzheimers disease and related dementias (ADRD). Ourmulti-PI team proposes a two-arm RCT called ADEPT-ICU (Attenuating DEPression with Internet CBT to SlowCognitive Decline in Older ICU Survivors) which will test the efficacy of an internet CBT intervention calledGood Days Ahead (GDA) to reduce the burden of subjective cognitive decline (SCD) in older ICU survivorswith moderate to severe depressive symptoms after ICU hospitalization. If our randomized controlled trial(RCT) is successful the GDA intervention could be an efficacious accessible and scalable approach toreduce the burden of SCD slow cognitive decline and improve quality of life (QoL) in older ICU survivors.

Project Title: Text-messaging Communication Micro-Intervention for Couples Coping with Advanced GI Cancer
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeMany couples have difficulty communicating about cancer-related concerns which can impede their ability tocope with the disease lead to increased psychological distress and negatively impact the quality of theirrelationships. While efficacious couple-based communication interventions have limited uptake due to theirtime-intensive nature; the proposed research project aims to address this problem by developing and pilottesting a text-messaging communication micro-intervention to increase reach and participation in couplescoping with advanced cancer. If successful we will have developed a brief targeted and scalable interventionthat could be integrated into routine oncology care resulting in better outcomes for both patients and theirfamily caregivers.

Project Title: Cognition Vascular Function and Physical Activity in Colorectal Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeColorectal cancer survivors (CRCS) are at an increased risk of negative physiological and psychologicalconsequences such as cognitive impairment and vascular dysfunction that might be worsened by physicalinactivity. The proposed study will yield a novel understanding of these variables in CRCS and also provide newinsights into the associations among these variables as well as providing understanding on the putativemechanism of vascular function mediating the relationship between physical activity and cognition.

Project Title: Avanzando Caminos (Leading Pathways): The Hispanic/Latino Cancer Survivorship Cohort Study.
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeSignificant disparities exist in prevalence invasiveness and mortality in specific cancers and across multiplepatient reported outcomes (PROs) including quality of life and symptom burden in Hispanic/Latinos (H/Ls) in theUS. The proposed cohort study will contribute to our understanding of how multiple factors (e.g. social culturalpsychosocial medical biological) contribute to cancer survivors outcomes including symptoms quality of lifeand mortality in a diverse sample of H/Ls regarding SES H/L origin and geography. As cancer is the leadingcause of death in Hispanic/Latinosthe largest minority population in the US that is expected to double in thenext 40 years the study will fill critical gaps in knowledge and provide much needed information to guidesecondary and tertiary prevention efforts.

Project Title: Stigmatizing Language in Cancer Care Electronic Health Records
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis project is relevant to public health because healthcare discrimination is common inequitably experiencedand associated with worse health outcomes. One way discrimination and stigma manifest in the healthcaresystem is through electronic health record (EHR) documentation; the prevalence and impact of EHRstigmatizing language in cancer care has not been investigated but may contribute to disparities in clinicaldecision-making and patient outcomes. Thus this research aligns with the NIHs mission to lead research incancer survivorship reduce health disparities and help all people live longer healthier lives.

Project Title: Survivorship and cost of care of cervical cancer patients in Puerto Rico in association with cervical cancer screening
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVECervical cancer incidence rates are increasing in Puerto Rico while screening uptake remains suboptimal. Theproposed diversity supplement will promote Jeslie Ramos Cartagena's career development in cancer healthdisparities and health services research. As part of the proposed work she will evaluate the history of cervicalcancer screening uptake (pap and/or HPV testing) and adherence among cervical cancer patients in PuertoRico as well as the survival and lifetime cost of care in association with cervical cancer screening.

Project Title: Supportive Care Needs in Asian Americans with Metastatic Cancer
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVECancer incidence is expected to increase to 23.6 million by 2030 worldwide and cancer is the leadingcause of death for Asian Americans whose numbers are rapidly rising to reach 40 million by 2050. Despiteinstances of greater cancer-specific mortality compared to other Asians and likely limited access to high-quality care due many experiencing language barriers (~50%) very little is known about supportive careneeds in Chinese- Vietnamese- and Korean-Americans with metastatic cancers. This project will fill acritical gap in our understanding and develop culturally relevant psychosocial resources/interventionsaimed at improving the quality of life of Asian Americans with metastatic cancers.

Project Title: Cancer Center Support Grant
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERVIEWCancer affects 1 in every 3 people in the US and as our population ages this fraction is expected to increase.Outcomes for cancer patients have improved over the last several decades but there is still a great burden ofcancer-related mortality and morbidity that is borne disproportionately by minorities and the economicallydisadvantaged. MD Anderson Cancer Center's mission is to eliminate cancer in Texas the nation and the worldthrough outstanding programs that integrate patient care research and prevention and through education forundergraduate and graduate students trainees professionals employees and the public. Our vision is to be thepremier cancer center in the world based on the excellence of our people our research-driven patient care andour science.

Project Title: Cancer Center Support Grant

Through a deep and broad spectrum of impactful research endeavors clinical andresearch education and training programs and the highest quality of patient care in multiple academic andcommunity settings the JCCC seeks to reduce the burden of cancer throughout its Los Angeles Countycatchment area and the nation.

Project Title: Cancer Center Support Grant
Public Health Relevance: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVEThe UCLA Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center (JCCC) strategic mission is to accelerate discoveries thatprevent and cure cancer. Through a deep and broad spectrum of impactful research endeavors clinical andresearch education and training programs and the highest quality of patient care in multiple academic andcommunity settings the JCCC seeks to reduce the burden of cancer throughout its Los Angeles Countycatchment area and the nation.

Project Title: Abramson Cancer Center Support Grant
Public Health Relevance: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT  Abramson Cancer CenterCancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States and prevalent in the ethnically diversecatchment area of the Abramson Cancer Center (ACC) which consists of 12 contiguous counties inPennsylvania New Jersey and Delaware in which 81.4% of ACC's patients reside. Through our ResearchPrograms and Community Outreach and Engagement the ACC addresses the burden imposed by highlyprevalent cancers in the catchment area including breast prostate lung colorectal melanoma andlymphoma. ACC basic clinical and population science research  along with Community Outreach andEngagement Activities  are integrated to prevent diagnose and treat these cancers and address cancer riskfactors to promote healthy living.

Project Title: Cancer Center Support Grant
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe Lineberger Comprehensive Cancer Center (LCCC) forms the nexus for researchers focused onunderstanding and identifying the mechanisms leading to the prevention of and treatments for cancer. LCCCis an integral component of the research mission at The University of North Carolina (UNC) at Chapel Hillcoalescing the cancer research capabilities of the Schools of Medicine Public Health Pharmacy and Nursingand the College of Arts and Sciences. The LCCC strives to reduce cancer incidence morbidity and mortality inNorth Carolina the United States and across the globe through innovative research cutting-edge treatmentsmulti-disciplinary training education and outreach.
Organization Name: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL

Project Title: Empowering Latinas to Obtain Guideline-Concordant Breast Cancer Screenings
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVELatinas suffer disproportionately from breast cancer relative to non-Latina Whites including late-stagediagnoses and worse mental health during diagnostic evaluation treatment and survivorship. This DiversitySupplement aims to extend the Parent Grant (R01CA261638) by providing insight into factors that contributeto Latinas' decisions to seek and provide social support after receiving abnormal mammogram results througha prospective qualitative study. Further the Diversity Supplement will train a bicultural bilingual Latina traineeseeking a Master's of Social Work degree in health communications and qualitative research methods whichwill enhance the diversity and research impact of the nation's workforce of emerging clinician scientists.

Project Title: An In-depth Examination of Psychological Distress among Black Breast Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEPsychological distress is a common symptom experienced by breast cancer survivors however data aboutpsychological distress in Black breast cancer survivors is sparse. This study will address these gaps byleveraging an existing longitudinal cohort data and primary qualitative interview and focus group data to a)explore healthcare delivery and psychosocial factors that contribute to psychological distress among Blackbreast cancer survivors and b) the strategies employed by Black breast cancer survivors to cope withpsychological distress. Findings from this study may offer opportunities to develop multilevel interventionsseeking to improve psychological distress outcomes in Black breast cancer survivors.

Project Title: Advancing help-seeking and recovery measures for sexual and gender minority survivors of gender-based violence
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeThe proposed study seeks to develop two instruments used to measure sexual and gender minority (SGM) help-seekingbarriers and recovery needs after experiencing gender-based violence (GBV). The proposed research is relevant to publichealth because unaddressed GBV victimization represents a key driver of SGM health disparities (e.g. suicidalitysubstance use depression HIV transmission) and understanding help-seeking barriers and recovery needs can helpimprove care linkages and identify additional areas for intervention and survivor support. This project is relevant to NIH'smission because it focuses on improving health for marginalized populations through identifying barriers to GBVtreatment access engagement and effectiveness with the goal to inform acceptable interventions to reduce healthdisparities and improve health outcomes for SGM populations.
Study Section: Social Psychology, Personality and Interpersonal Processes Study Section[SPIP]

Project Title: A Nurse-Led Coping and Supportive Care Intervention to Improve Psychosocial Outcomes of Patients with Triple-Negative Breast Cancer During the Transition from Curative Therapy to Surveillance
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEPatients with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) undergo rigorous treatment regimens yet frequentlyexperience high cancer recurrence rates and cancer death leading to uncertainty distress and poor quality oflife. The proposed research project aims to develop refine and pilot test a nurse-led coping and supportivecare intervention for patients with TNBC during the critical transition from curative therapy to surveillancedesigned to alleviate distress improve quality of life and increase stress-coping skills. By focusing on thispreviously understudied high-risk group of patients with breast cancer study findings will inform futureresearch utilizing risk-stratified survivorship care models with potential applications to other high-risk cancersurvivors.

Project Title: Dance-based Avenues to Advance Nonpharmacologic treatment of Chemotherapy Effects (DAANCE): a multicenter trial
Public Health Relevance: NarrativeUp to 80% of breast cancer survivors experience chemotherapy-induced neuropathy that impairs quality of lifeand increases fall risk long into survivorship yet treatment options for neuropathy remain limited. The successfultreatment will target neurophysiologic mechanisms for restoring function while addressing patient-reportedsymptoms and participation in treatment. Toward this end we propose to study a noninvasive socialsensorimotor intervention  Adapted Argentine Tango  which targets motor control restoration symptomalleviation and treatment participation in concert.

Project Title: Development of a novel survey to screen for chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy in young children
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEChemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN) is a debilitating condition that occurs in up to 87% ofchildren treated with chemotherapy and often persists in long-term childhood cancer survivors. CIPN isparticularly challenging to identify in young children because there are no validated instruments to measureCIPN in children less than five years old even though 40% of children at risk for CIPN are in this age groupand early intervention can improve their symptoms. The overarching goal of this proposal is to develop apatient-centered clinician-guided instrument to screen for CIPN in young children and collect preliminary datato inform future implementation.

Project Title: Randomized controlled trial of FoRtitude: Targeted eHealth intervention to reduce fear of recurrence among breast cancer survivors in community oncology settings
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEA substantial proportion of breast cancer survivors report fear of cancer recurrence following cancertreatment yet few interventions utilizing scalable eHealth methods and targeting fear of recurrencehave been empirically evaluated. The purpose of this large multisite phase III randomized clinical trialis to evaluate whether an eHealth intervention (FoRtitude) that teaches cognitive behavior therapy-based coping strategies and healthy behaviors tailored to manage fear of recurrence can reduce fearof recurrence depression and anxiety; improve quality of life; and reduce fear of recurrence-relatedhealth care utilization and physiologic dysregulation (allostatic load).
Organization Name: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
Study Section: Biobehavioral Medicine and Health Outcomes Study Section[BMHO]

Project Title: Informatics strategies to improve immune-related adverse event detection in cancer patients
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEImmune checkpoint inhibitors dramatically improve prognosis for many cancer patients but come at the cost ofa new class of immune-related adverse events that reduce overall quality-of-life and the net benefit oftreatment. This proposal seeks to automatically detect immune-related adverse event phenotypes from theelectronic health record to support timely data-driven cancer care that enhances survivorship. To achieve thisgoal we will develop and clinically validate advanced informatics and artificial intelligence technologies suchas deep learning language models to automate immune-related adverse event monitoring and data collection.
Study Section: Clinical Data Management and Analysis Study Section[CDMA]

Project Title: Patient Priorities Survivorship Care for Older Women with Breast Cancer
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on adopting a patient-priorities approach to decision making during survivorship care for older women with breastcancer and multiple chronic conditions. If shown to be feasible and acceptable to patients andclinicians this approach maximizes benefits that matter to older women with breast cancer whileminimizing harm and burden. This research is relevant to the NIA's mission because of its focuson care for older adults driven by patient's values goals and preferences while supporting thefurther training of Dr. Giza to become a leader in geriatric oncology care.
Organization Name: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON

Project Title: Overcoming Immunotherapy Resistance Through Opioid Antagonism in Head and Neck Cancer
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEImmune checkpoint blockade is a promising therapeutic approach for head and neck cancer however fewerthan 20% of patients will respond to treatment. The proposed studies investigate the impact of opioids used forcancer pain management on the anti-tumor immune response and test the efficacy of peripheral opioidreceptor antagonism to improve response to immunotherapy.

Project Title: Children's Oncology Group NCI Community Oncology Research Program (NCORP) Research Base grant
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeThe Childrens Oncology Group (COG) is the worlds largest organization devoted exclusively to childhood andadolescent cancer research with more than 9000 members at over 220 leading childrens hospitals universitiesand cancer centers across the U.S. Canada and other countries. The COG conducts therapeutic trials as wellas cancer control and cancer care delivery research studies to improve outcomes across diverse populationsincluding adolescents and young adults with cancer.

The COG conducts therapeutic trials as wellas cancer control and cancer care delivery research studies to improve outcomes across diverse populationsincluding adolescents and young adults with cancer.

Project Title: Detroit Research on Cancer Survivors (Detroit ROCS)
Public Health Relevance: Project Narrative/RelevanceAfrican Americans continue to have poor outcomes after a cancer diagnosis and few African Americancohorts exist to support studies of the determinants of cancer prognosis and progression survivalquality of life and post-treatment outcomes. The proposed continuation of follow-up of this cohort ofpopulation-based African American cancer survivors will provide longer-term outcomes data andbiospecimens for a research agenda driven by priorities in the African American community and aimedat understanding and improving cancer outcomes in this population.

Project Title: Socioeconomic determinants of childhood cancer outcomes in a large contemporary cohort
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeDespite improvements in childhood cancer survival over the last several decades marked racial ethnic andsocioeconomic disparities in outcomes persist. Thus understanding the socioeconomic factors contributing todisparities in relapse toxicities and survival may allow for intervention measures in the future.
Study Section: Cancer, Heart, and Sleep Epidemiology B Study Section[CHSB]

Project Title: OPTIMISE: A Shared Care Approach for Improving Comprehensive Care of Cancer Patients with Comorbidities in A Safety-Net System
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEMedically underserved patients have the highest burden of multiple chronic conditions and are at increased riskfor poor outcomes during and after cancer treatment. As medically underserved complex cancer patients maylack healthcare knowledge and access to supportive care their health outcomes and care transitions might beimproved by enhancing communication and collaboration between their oncologists and primary care providers(PCPs). This study tests and evaluates a novel shared care model for complex cancer survivors calledOPTIMISE that shifts the timing of thinking about survivorship to point of diagnosis and seeks to develop a clinicalinfrastructure to support continuity of care from cancer diagnosis through post-treatment survivorship.

Project Title: Discovering the role of YES1 in triple negative breast cancer
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVETriple Negative Breast Cancer (TNBC) is a highly aggressive disease that has limited treatment options. Thisproposal focuses on determining if a protein called YES1 may underlie the malignancy associated with TNBCand the molecular pathways it uses to cause poor patient outcomes. This work will also provide a proof-of-concept in model systems testing the possibility of inhibiting YES1 with drugs that may ultimately lead to a moreeffective approach for treating TNBC.

Project Title: Adapting and implementing evidence-based breast cancer follow-up in primary care
Public Health Relevance: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCEThe numbers of breast cancer survivors are increasing and their symptom burden after treatment is significant.Despite a growing evidence base of symptom management and risk reduction strategies use of theseactivities in primary care practice remains suboptimal. This study engages critical stakeholders in identifyingand prioritizing evidence based activities to enhance breast cancer survivorship care and has potential toimpact implementation strategies used throughout the U.S. for long-term care for patients with a history ofbreast cancer.
Study Section: Science of Implementation in Health and Healthcare Study Section[SIHH]

Project Title: Effectiveness and implementation of a health system intervention to improve quality of cancer care for rural underserved patients
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe 60 million rural residents of the United States have a lower rate of new cases of cancer per year comparedto urban residents but have a higher rate of cancer deaths per year partly due to the greater difficulty inaccessing high-quality cancer treatment in rural areas. As rural patients are less likely to receive care in urbancancer centers with cancer specialists who treat very large numbers of cancer patients an effective strategyused by the University of Kentucky Markey Cancer Center has been to share their expertise and resourceswith smaller community hospitals across Kentucky to help improve their quality of care. We propose to studythe Kentucky model in order to identify and characterize its core functions (i.e. what made it effective inimproving quality of care in community hospitals) adapt it to a new rural setting and determine its value to thehospitals and impact on cancer care.

Project Title: NOURISH-T+: A Randomized Control Trial Targeting Parents in Promoting Healthy Eating and Exercise Behaviors in Pediatric Cancer Survivors with Overweight/Obesity
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeApproximately 40-50% of off-treatment pediatric cancer survivors (PCS) are overweight orobese; thereby increasing their risk for negative long-term physical health complications. Usingour successful pilot trial testing the preliminary feasibility and efficacy of NOURISH-for HealthyTransitions (NOURISH-T 5R21CA167259) as a base we address obesity in PCS by targetingparents as agents for change in modeling healthy eating and physical activity behaviors topromote positive PCS health behavior change and long-term healthy weight. This multi-siteapplication addresses the public health epidemic of obesity by conducting a randomized controltrial to test the efficacy of our intervention NOURISH-T+ across a diverse sample of PCS andtheir parents at four pediatric oncology clinics with the goal of establishing a framework forfuture translation and dissemination of NOURISH-T+.
Study Section: Psychosocial Development, Risk and Prevention Study Section[PDRP]

Project Title: Enhanced Pain Coping in Cancer (EPIC)
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEChronic pain induced by aromatase inhibitor therapy is a common and debilitating symptom impacting breastcancer survivors. The Enhanced Pain Coping in Cancer (EPIC) trial investigates a novel scalableneuroscience-based non-pharmacological virtual intervention with potential to change the paradigm of painclinical care for millions of breast cancer survivors with aromatase inhibitor-associated arthralgia.
Other PI or Project Leader(s): GARLAND, ERIC LEE; HANLEY, ADAM WESLEY
Study Section: Biobehavioral Medicine and Health Outcomes Study Section[BMHO]

Project Title: The Lymphoma Epidemiology of Outcomes (LEO) Cohort Study (Diversity Supplement - Alexis Romero)
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVENHL is the most common hematologic malignancy and there are many unmet clinical and public health needsof this growing patient population. The goal of the LEO infrastructure grant is to support a cohort of over 16000non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) patients in order to address broad and cutting-edge research that identifiesclinical epidemiologic (including lifestyle and other exposures) host genetic tumor and treatment factors andthe interaction among these factors on short and long-term outcomes. The efforts of this Research Supplementare well aligned with the ultimate goal of identifying new approaches to improve the survival and well-being ofNHL patients.

Project Title: Virtual Mindful After Cancer Intervention to Promote Sexual Health for Breast and Gynecologic Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: Despite the high prevalence of sexual health concerns in cancer survivorship these concerns often gounaddressed. This project is expected to prepare our team for the successful launch of a multisite pragmatictrial to evaluate whether the virtual Mindful After Cancer intervention can be integrated into routine cancer andimprove sexual health outcomes for breast and gynecological cancer survivors. This can make a significantcontribution toward improving equity in access to comprehensive sexual health services and reducing theburden of cancer for this population.

Project Title: Comparison of Symptom Burden/Toxicity Neurocognitive Change and Functional Outcomes in Pediatric Brain Tumor Patients Treated with Proton vs. Photon Radiotherapy.
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEMany consider proton beam radiotherapy (PBRT) to be a promising treatment for children with brain tumors asit may preserve cognitive functioning without sacrificing disease control. This will be the first large-scale studyto prospectively compare symptom burden treatment toxicity and neurocognitive change between patientstreated with PBRT vs. conventional photon radiotherapy on comparable treatment protocols and to assessimportant measures of daily functioning that will quantify the clinical significance of any differences identifiedbetween groups in survivorship. Ultimately this line of research is intended to: (1) help physicians and familiesbetter understand the relative effect of PBRT on symptoms and neurocognitive functioning to inform treatmentdecisions and (2) provide functional outcome data to be used toward justifying or reconciling the high cost andaccess limitations currently associated with PBRT.
Study Section: Nursing and Related Clinical Sciences Study Section[NRCS]

Project Title: Impact of Rural Hospital Closures on Cancer Outcomes and Cancer Racial Disparity among Medicare Beneficiaries
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis proposal is relevant to rural public health in the cancer care continuum. Understanding the impact of ruralhospital closures on cancer outcomes will provide critical insights into their consequences on cancer care andracial/ethnic disparities. It will also inform healthcare professionals and policymakers about resource allocationand the development of tailored interventions to mitigate the negative effects of rural hospital closures ondisadvantaged rural communities and populations.

Project Title: Determining the Feasibility of Virtual Tailored Music-Based Relaxation for Anxiety Among Adolescent and Young Adult Cancer Survivors.
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeThe proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on the testing of a psychosocialintervention for the management of anxiety among adolescents and young adult cancer survivors.Approximately 50% of adolescent and young adult cancer survivors will experience clinically significant anxietyin the months to years following cancer treatment. The results are expected to have a positive impact becausedemonstration that virtual tailored music-based relaxation is feasible to implement among adolescent andyoung adult cancer survivors will inform the design of a Phase II clinical trial to demonstrate efficacy of theintervention for anxiety a distressing side effect of cancer treatment for which little is known about how to bestsupport the psychosocial needs of adolescent and young adult cancer survivors.
Organization Name: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR

Project Title: Evaluation of clinical and social factors associated with deficit accumulation trajectories in older survivors with early-stage non-small cell lung cancer
Public Health Relevance: Project narrativeAging involves a gradual clinical decline in cognitive and physical function and often the development ofvarious comorbidities. However significant life events such as a cancer diagnosis cancer treatment or otherindividual-level and societal-level factors can accelerate clinical decline and aging in cancer survivorscompared to other older people without a cancer diagnosis. The completion of this study will identify targetablemultilevel aging risk factors in the older population with lung cancer as well as provide a valuable monitoringtool to predict dynamic risk of aging-related clinical decline allowing for a deeper understanding of drivers ofaging acceleration and timely intervention before clinical decline occurs.
Organization Name: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
Study Section: Career Development For Early Career Investigators Study Section [AGCD-2]

Project Title: Adaptation and Testing of an Evidence-Based Sexual Health Communication Skills Training Intervention for Patients with Prostate Cancer
Public Health Relevance: Prostate cancer (PCa) is the most common non-cutaneous cancer in U.S. men and causes significant short-and long-term sexual side effects (i.e. sexual dysfunction) in up to 90% of patients. Although multipleevidence-based therapies for sexual dysfunction (e.g. psychotherapy medications surgery) exist many PCapatients face significant barriers to communicating with their providers about sexual dysfunction which impairssexual recovery. We propose to rigorously adapt and pilot test an evidence-based sexual healthcommunication skills training intervention for PCa patients to improve patient-provider communication aboutsexual health in PCa care and thereby facilitate improved sexual recovery and sexual health outcomesamong PCa patients.
Organization Name: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE

Project Title: Understanding disparities in cardiovascular toxicity among breast cancer survivors in Arkansas
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular (CV) toxicities from common cancer therapies (trastuzumab anthracyclines or left chestradiation) can lead to cardiovascular disease (heart failure myocardial infarction and stroke) and are morecommon among marginalized racial and ethnic groups and those with adverse social determinants of health(SDOH) such as lower levels of socioeconomic status and living in disadvantaged neighborhoods or ruralareas. Yet the role of complex SDOH in CV toxicity disparities among breast cancer survivors is unknown andfew studies have considered the intersections among race ethnicity and other SDOH. This K01 aims to: 1)identify the extent of disparities in incident CV toxicity among breast cancer survivors in Arkansas based onrace ethnicity neighborhood socioeconomic status and geography; and 2) develop a predictive algorithm forrisk stratification in breast cancer survivors at high risk for CV toxicity using machine-learning approaches thatincorporate race ethnicity and SDOH to move beyond describing disparities in CV toxicities to informingtargeted interventions to improve the CV health of breast cancer survivors.
Organization Name: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
Study Section: NHLBI Mentored Clinical and Basic Science Study Section[MCBS-E(MA)]

Project Title: Preventing Cervical Cancer through HPV Self-collection and Patient Navigation among Women Living with Chronic Conditions and Social Vulnerability
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis project seeks to pilot test the feasibility and acceptability of the PINPOINT intervention (PreventingCervIcal caNcer through HPV self-cOllection and patIent NavigaTion) for women with type 2 diabetes obesityand social vulnerability. The overarching objective of this career development award is to support RahmaMkuu Ph.D. MPHs career development into an independent implementation scientist addressing cancerdisparities.
