Project Title: Infrastructure for Pathways a Prospective Study of Breast Cancer Survivorship
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Pathways Study is a multi-ethnic prospective cohort study of women diagnosed and treated forbreast cancer in the Kaiser Permanente Northern California (KPNC) integrated health care system that isdesigned to examine multi-level factors to improve the breast cancer experience and outcomes. The studyincludes patient-reported health and lifestyle behaviors such as food intake physical activity and quality of life;molecular and genetic factors from blood specimens; a tumor bank; clinical factors from electronic healthrecords; neighborhood factors from geospatial databases and virtual neighborhood audits; and a CommunityAdvisory Board to help guide infrastructure activities and prioritize research use of this cohort. We propose toenhance this resource in various ways including continued follow-up new data linkages with environmentalexposure and statewide health care utilization data and with creation of a complementary data-only cohort ofwomen diagnosed with breast cancer in KPNC from 2006 to 2023 thus cementing this resource as theoutstanding setting for epidemiologic studies of breast cancer survivorship and outcomes.

Project Title: Novel Strategy of PDE5-mTOR Inhibition in Attenuation of Cancer  Drug Cardiotoxicity
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeDoxorubicin alone or its combination with kinase inhibitor are highly effective strategies fortreatment of breast cancer but their utility is limited due to a major side effect involving heartfailure. Currently there is no effective therapy available to reduce or eliminate the risk of heartfailure in cancer patients treated with these agents. We propose to study a novel combination ofphosphodiesterase 5 inhibitor sildenafil (Viagra) and the potent anti-rejection drug rapamycin toreduce cardiac side effects and improve the efficacy of breast cancer treatment with doxorubicinand doxorubicin with the kinase inhibitor.

Project Title: Randomized trial of REVITALIZE: A telehealth intervention to reduce fatigue interference among adults with advanced ovarian cancer on PARP inhibitors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEIn the era of precision oncology more patients are living longer with advanced cancer yet many of the newtreatments cause unrelenting fatigue which interferes with daily life and may lead to non-adherence ordiscontinuation of these breakthrough therapies. Despite this there are few effective evidence-based treatmentsfor fatigue in metastatic cancer. This study rigorously evaluates REVITALIZE--a well-piloted telehealthintervention designed to improve fatigue outcomes in patients with advanced ovarian cancer taking PARPinhibitors--in a fully-powered randomized trial in patients treated at both academic and community cancer clinicsthat serve diverse communities.
Study Section: Interdisciplinary Clinical Care in Specialty Care Settings Study Section[ICSC]

Project Title: Chronic Health Conditions in Survivors of Down Syndrome-Associated Leukemia
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEChildren with Down syndrome are at increased risk for acute leukemia treatment-related toxicities but fewstudies have investigated survivorship outcomes in this subgroup. The proposed work will compare chronichealth conditions neuropsychological outcomes and quality of life in Down syndrome survivors of acuteleukemia to age and sex-matched children with Down syndrome and no history of cancer. Our objective is tocomprehensively characterize outcomes in survivors of Down syndrome-associated acute leukemia andidentify related risk factors in order to inform clinical practice guidelines for survivorship care of thisunderstudied and vulnerable population.
Other PI or Project Leader(s): JACOLA, LISA M; LUPO, PHILIP ; RABIN, KAREN R

Project Title: PEDIATRIC ONCOLOGY CLINICAL RESEARCH TRAINING PROGRAM
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis Pediatric Oncology Clinical Research Training Program (POCRTP) provides a comprehensive clinicalresearch educational program that trains pediatric oncologists in clinical research; the program seeks to producethe next generation of leaders in the field of pediatric cancer clinical research. The trainees designated PaulCalabresi Scholars receive a mentored training experience in the design implementation conduct andanalysis of clinical research trials. The ultimate goal of the POCRTP is to educate Scholars to translate basicresearch discoveries into innovative treatments using effective clinical trials thereby improving the prognosis ofchildren with cancer.
Study Section: Institutional Training and Education Study Section (F)[NCI-F]

Project Title: Breast Cancer Family Registry
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVE: The Breast Cancer Family Registry (BCFR) Cohort is an international cohort in the U.S. Canadaand Australia comprised of multi-generational families (33037 women and 6992 men from 15056 families) thatstarted in 1995. We will strengthen and continue to provide to the research community an important and uniquelong-term family cohort with extensive epidemiologic and molecular data to address cutting-edge and clinicallyimportant research questions on breast cancer susceptibility outcomes survival and survivorship with the overallgoal of advancing knowledge of the biology of breast cancer development and progression so as to reduce thecancer burden and cancer disparities.
Other PI or Project Leader(s): ANDRULIS, IRENE ; COLONNA, SARAH ; DALY, MARY BERYL; GENKINGER, JEANINE M.; HOPPER, JOHN L; JOHN, ESTHER M.

Project Title: Mobile Device CBT for Chemotherapy-Related Cognitive Dysfunction: A Multi-Center Randomized Controlled Trial
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe proposed research will examine the efficacy of a videoconference-delivered cognitive-behavioral therapy(CBT) Memory and Attention Adaptation Training (MAAT) vs. an attention control condition (supportivetherapy; ST) in a large multi-site randomized controlled trial (RCT) to improve subjective and objectivecognitive functioning in breast cancer survivors with chemotherapy-related cognitive dysfunction (CRCD).Another goal of the research is to use functional MRI (fMRI) to evaluate underlying changes in brain activationpatterns that are believed to be associated with positive effects of MAAT. If successful results of this work will:(1) produce an evidence-based treatment that can be immediately disseminated to cancer centers and otherhealthcare settings to treat CRCD and (2) help inform further treatment development through improvedunderstanding of mechanisms that promote CRCD recovery.
Study Section: Behavioral Medicine, Interventions and Outcomes Study Section[BMIO]

Project Title: Massey Cancer Center -Cancer Center Support Grant
Public Health Relevance: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe mission of the Massey Cancer Center (MCC) is to reduce the state cancer burden for all Virginians byaddressing the confluence between biological social and policy drivers through high-impact cutting-edgeresearch; person-centered care across the continuum from prevention through survivorship; communityintegration; and training the next generation of community-centric researchers and healthcare professionals. Thecore of this mission has been supported by the National Cancer Institutes Cancer Center Support Grant (CCSG)since 1975 and the MCC is seeking renewal of this award for another five years. The CCSG supports effortsacross the MCC senior and programmatic leadership; administration; community outreach and engagement;cancer research training and education coordination; promotion of center-wide diversity equity and inclusion;shared resource support and management; clinical research infrastructure; and developmental funding tosupporting team-based transdisciplinary research strategies focused on well-defined catchment area priorities.

Project Title: University of Florida Health Cancer Center Support Grant
Public Health Relevance: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe mission of the University of Florida Health Cancer Center (UFHCC) is to prevent detect and ultimately curecancer and address the unique challenges of the cancer burden faced by the population we serve by facilitatinginnovative collaborative transdisciplinary cancer research. UFHCC will achieve these goals through discoveryand research innovations in cancer mechanisms prevention screening and treatment while training the nextgeneration of cancer scientists and leaders and engaging the communities and populations we serve.

Project Title: Roswell Park Cancer Center Support Grant
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVERoswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center is one of only a small number of freestanding NCI-designatedcomprehensive cancer centers and the only comprehensive center in New York State (NYS) outside ofManhattan. Roswell Park has a rich history of leadership in basic discovery translational clinical and population-based science in cancer research. In recent years Roswell Park has pushed the boundaries of excellence incancer research and has experienced exponential growth in faculty recruitment programmatic and scientificexcellence a robust clinical trial portfolio and accrual to investigator-initiated trials population cancer sciencedevelopment and a broader footprint in the WNY catchment area and community with a focus on diversity equityand inclusion. We propose here to be a leader in the development of innovative approaches in cancer researchto improve the quality of care for our patients in our catchment area and beyond to enhance collaborative effortsbetween scientists and physicians toward a more effective translation of our discoveries into paradigm changingpatient practices and interventions and policies to train and develop the next generation of investigators throughinnovative oncology-focused programs to focus on the needs of our catchment area of WNY relevant to ourcancer burden and related disparities through research and outreach using effective strategies for educationprevention treatment and survivorship and to cultivate value and support diversity equity inclusion andbelonging across our cancer center employees scientists physicians nurses and healthcare staff students andtrainees and leadership toward a more productive and diverse workplace and to serve our community moreeffectively. Roswell Park continues to play a primary role in discovery and innovation that enable us to deliverthe best cancer care to our patients in New York State around the country and around the world.

Project Title: The EPICS (Engaging Primary care in Cancer Survivorship) study: A trial of novel models of care for cancer survivors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEWe are currently facing unprecedented challenges in survivorship care delivery including serious gaps insurvivorship care (e.g. underuse of guideline-recommended cancer surveillance services and underuse ofrecommended preventive care services); these issues are compounded by the growing population of cancersurvivors and the predicted oncology workforce shortage. To address these issues we will conduct aprospective cluster randomized trial of two models of cancer survivorship care in early-stage colorectal cancerand breast cancer survivors cared for in a community-based integrated health care setting. We will test theefficacy of an embedded PCP model (experimental condition) in which survivorship-trained PCPs areembedded within an oncology practice compared to the oncology physician model (usual care) that is thedefault condition in this healthcare system.

Project Title: Family-Centered Co-Design of a Technology-Facilitated Intervention for Family Caregivers of Critical Care Survivors
Public Health Relevance: Family caregivers play a central role during a Veterans critical care (medical care for a life-threatening illnessor injury) hospitalization and survivorship. Yet up to 73% of caregivers experience anxiety and 97%experience depression during a critically ill patients hospital stay. Addressing family caregiver needsincluding informational and emotional processing social support and self-care during key moments early ina familys crisis may moderate the development of caregiver psychological distress. This research focuseson determining common key moments in the caregiver experience that can lead to distress (Aim 1)designing psychosocial intervention components to meet caregiver needs during these key moments (Aim 2)and testing the feasibility and acceptability of these components (Aim 3) which seek to moderate thedevelopment of psychological distress among caregivers of critically ill Veterans.

Project Title: Translational Research in Cancer
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL AND SIX ESSENTIAL CHARACTERISTICSThe overarching goal of the Sidney Kimmel Cancer Center (SKCC) is to leverage research expertise to reducethe overall incidence burden and mortality from cancer in Greater Philadelphia and beyond. SKCC goals arerealized through unique strengths in addressing cancer problems through collaboration across basic clinicaland population research disciplines. SKCC is nucleated at Thomas Jefferson University (TJU) and enriched byfully integrated research consortium partner from Drexel University (DU); building on these strengths SKCCfocuses on addressing catchment area needs through nurturing transdisciplinary research expandinginnovative research capabilities extending outreach and clinical research into the community and enhancingthe pace of bench-to-bedside discovery.

Project Title: Incidence and Time on Onset of Cardiovascular Risk Factors and Cardiovascular Disease in Adult Survivors of Adolescent and Young Adult Cancer and Association with Exercise
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVECardiovascular complications negatively affect the quality and quantity of life in cancer survivors. This projectwill explore the role that known cardiotoxic treatments have on cardiovascular complications and the roleexercise may play in mitigating these late effects within a specific age group (those diagnosed between the agesof 15 and 20 years old) of cancer survivors. This award will support my development towards becoming anindependent nurse scientist dedicated to understanding the effects of cardiotoxic treatments on adolescent andyoung adult cancer survivors.
Organization Name: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL

Project Title: Accelerated biological and phenotypic aging in hematopoietic cell transplant survivors: Social support as a protective factor
Public Health Relevance: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTHHematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) is a widely used treatment for hematologic cancers; however it canaccelerate biological aging in recipients by up to 15 years and many survivors experience long-term symptomsthat resemble an accelerated aging phenotype. This project aims to elucidate the important protectiveelements of social relationships and identify concrete modifiable behavioral factors that contribute to biologicaland phenotypic aging in HCT survivors and can be used to develop biologically informed interventions toimprove quality of life and prolong the healthspan of individuals with accelerated aging.
Study Section: Behavior and Social Science of Aging Study Section[NIA-S]

Project Title: Music listening interventions for children receiving mechanical ventilation: A mechanistic trial
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEChildren who are critically ill and receiving mechanical ventilation are at increased risks for experiencing highlevels of stress and pain which negatively impacts immediate and long-term health. The current standard ofcare for treating stress and pain is to provide analgesic and sedative medications which are associated withincreased risk of delirium and posttraumatic stress disorder. This randomized crossover trial will compare theeffects of live and recorded music listening on biomarkers of stress and pain among children receivingmechanical ventilation in the pediatric intensive care unit to identify the key components of a music listeningintervention and explore its mechanism of action i.e. the biological pathway through which music listeningdecreases stress and pain.
Study Section: Function, Integration, and Rehabilitation Sciences Study Section[CHHD-K]

Project Title: Cancer Center Support Grant
Public Health Relevance: Narrative OverallThe City of Hope Comprehensive Cancer Center leverages the scientific expertise of 175 cancer-focusedinvestigators who form five productive Research Programs spanning basic translational clinical and population-based research that are supported by unique institutional resources and a robust cancer-focused researchfunding base. An active clinical trials portfolio builds on institutional research discoveries to facilitate advancesacross the translational research continuum that benefit the population of a diverse Catchment Area and thelarger community of people at risk for or affected by cancer.

Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeWe will study how survival after transplantation can be improved for patients of all races through a betterunderstanding of the genes that help to eliminate cancer cells.This information will help to lower risks throughindividualized treatment options for future patients.

Project Title: E-PROOF: E-intervention for Protein Intake and Resistance Training to Optimize Function
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEPhysical function limitations among older cancer survivors is associated with multiple negative health outcomesrepresenting a critical problem in public health. This study will implement and assess the efficacy of the firstonline dietary and resistance training intervention to improve older cancer survivors physical function andimprove associated health outcomes (muscle strength dietary quality health-related quality of life self-efficacyweight management). The expected outcomes of this study will inform the development of large-scale trials andhave implications that can lead to efficacious behavioral interventions in health promotion for older cancersurvivors.
Study Section: Lifestyle Change and Behavioral Health Study Section[LCBH]

Project Title: (PQ3) Addressing Cancer Treatment Disparities for Persons with HIV
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEPeople with HIV (PWH) may have poorer cancer outcomes than people without HIV (HIV-) but few largestudies have evaluated differences in specific cancer care delivery outcomes by HIV status. Within theVeteran's Administration and Kaiser Permanente we will investigate reasons for disparities between PWH andmatched HIV- persons in delays in cancer treatment initiation completion and safety as well as short- andlong-term outcomes of cancer recurrences mortality and risk of chronic health conditions. Study findings havepotential to identify intervention targets inform HIV-specific cancer treatment guidelines and improve cancercare delivery and outcomes for PWH.

Project Title: Optimizing Functional Outcomes of Older Survivors After Chemotherapy
Public Health Relevance: Project Narrative:Almost 50% of cancer survivors will be 75 years or over by 2040 and the numbers of older survivors andcaregivers are expected to grow with the aging of the population. Older cancer survivors experience physicaland cognitive function impairments from curative-intent chemotherapy yet no standard aging-sensitiveintervention exists to improve outcomes. The overarching goal of this proposal is to evaluate whether astandardized Geriatric Evaluation and Management intervention (which surveils for the medical physical andpsychological effects of chemotherapy to guide management recommendations including referrals to relevantdisciplines) combined with a Survivorship Health Promotion program can improve outcomes of older survivorsand their caregivers in the transition following curative-intent chemotherapy.
Other PI or Project Leader(s): JANELSINS, MICHELLE C; MUSTIAN, KAREN M.

Project Title: Assessing Cervical Cancer Healthcare Inequities in Diverse Populations: The ACHIEVE Study
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe proposed study seeks to examine upstream indicators of structural racism as contributors to inequities inreceipt of guideline-concordant cervical cancer treatment and survival in a diverse population-based study.Guided by the NIMHD research framework and socio-structural models this mixed-methods study will leveragetwo NCI population-based Surveillance Epidemiology and End Results Program registries (New Jersey StateCancer Registry and Los Angeles Cancer Surveillance Program) to prospectively examine the impact of micro-mezzo- and macro-level factors with an emphasis on health system-level factors on receipt of guidelineconcordant treatment for and survival from cervical cancer. Successful accomplishment of the proposed aimswill result in high impact findings on the multilevel causes of suboptimal cervical cancer treatment and poorersurvival outcomes among marginalized groups to develop actionable system-level practice and policy change toaddress the persistent cervical cancer inequities.
Study Section: Organization and Delivery of Health Services Study Section[ODHS]

Project Title: The Pacific Aging and Cancer Studies (PACS): An Infrastructure Advancing the Use of Digital Biomarkers and Related Technologies for Research on Functional Aging and Survivorship in Cancer
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEWith a doubling in the number of older cancer survivors in just a few decades preventing falls dysfunction anddisability from systemic cancer treatment is an urgent public health issue. Our phased R21/R33 study willadvance an infrastructure advancing the use of digital biomarkers and related technologies for research onfunctional aging and survivorship in cancer.
Study Section: Clinical Management in General Care Settings Study Section[CMGC]

Project Title: Managing symptoms and psychological distress during oral anti-cancer treatment
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeUse of oral anti-cancer treatment has increased significantly over the past decade for many cancers. Inexchange for eliminating trip to infusion units cancer survivors on oral agents must self-manage theirsymptoms at home. This project tests a highly scalable automated intervention for monitoring and managingsymptoms during oral anti-cancer treatment adding a counseling intervention for survivors in need with highpsychological distress.
Other PI or Project Leader(s): BADGER, TERRY A; CRANE, TRACY E
Study Section: Biobehavioral Medicine and Health Outcomes Study Section[BMHO]

Project Title: Self-Management to Optimize Survivorship Care and Outcomes in Lung and Colorectal Cancer
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeThe overall purpose of this R01 grant application entitled Self-Management to Optimize Survivorship Care andOutcomes in Lung and Colorectal Cancer is to test whether an advanced practice nurse (APRN)-led SurvivorSelf-Management (SSM) Intervention can improve care coordination communication and quality of life in lungand colorectal cancer. In collaboration with the Beckman Research Institute of City of Hope and the Universityof California Riverside we have a unique opportunity to understand whether a self-management andoncology/primary care shared care model can optimize outcomes for lung and colorectal cancer survivors agrowing population that are traditionally underrepresented in cancer research. Completion of the study willimprove our understanding on how to best transition lung and colorectal cancer survivors to post-treatmentfollow-up care.

Project Title: SPHERE (Survivorship Plan Health Record) Implementation Trial
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVETo understand the effectiveness and implementation of the SCP-PHR we will conduct a hybrid type 1effectiveness-implementation trial consisting of the following components: (A) a randomized clinicaleffectiveness trial and (B) a mixed methods implementation study.

Project Title: Effectiveness and implementation of a health system intervention to improve quality of cancer care for rural underserved patients
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe 60 million rural residents of the United States have a lower rate of new cases of cancer per year comparedto urban residents but have a higher rate of cancer deaths per year partly due to the greater difficulty inaccessing high-quality cancer treatment in rural areas. As rural patients are less likely to receive care in urbancancer centers with cancer specialists who treat very large numbers of cancer patients an effective strategyused by the University of Kentucky Markey Cancer Center has been to share their expertise and resourceswith smaller community hospitals across Kentucky to help improve their quality of care. We propose to studythe Kentucky model in order to identify and characterize its core functions (i.e. what made it effective inimproving quality of care in community hospitals) adapt it to a new rural setting and determine its value to thehospitals and impact on cancer care.

Project Title: Colon Cancer Family Registry Cohort
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe Colon Cancer Family Registry Cohort is well established and has been the resource of many studies ofcolorectal cancer. If the infrastructure grant is funded the public health relevance gained by an additional 5-years of follow-up and innovative characterization to further enhance the cohort will lead to a new wave ofresearch for risk factors for the colorectal cancer new ways of preventing the disease and new ways to treatthe disease.
Other PI or Project Leader(s): BUCHANAN, DANIEL DAVID; GALLINGER, STEVEN ; LE MARCHAND, LOIC ; PAI, RISH ; PHIPPS, AMANDA IRENE; SCHMIT, STEPHANIE L.

Project Title: Next Generation Therapies for Fertility Preservation in Male Cancer Patients
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeIn a preclinical Rhesus macaque model of cancer survivorship this application will to develop next generationtherapies to preserve and restore the fertility of males who are at risk of infertility due to their medicaltreatments. We will test a combination of pharmacological- and tissue-based therapies to preserve and/orrestore fertility in a monkey model and with testicular tissues from human patients. Progress in the proposedapplication will expand the menu of reproductive options available to patients who have frozen their testiculartissues prior to gonadotoxic therapies.
Study Section: Cellular, Molecular and Integrative Reproduction Study Section[CMIR]

Project Title: Coordinating Center for Research Centers for Improving Management of Symptoms During and Following Cancer Treatment
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeMillions of cancer patients across the cancer care continuum suffer from complications associated with theirillness including high symptom burden and poor quality of life. RTI Internationals Coordinating Centerproposes to continue support of the Improving Management of Symptoms Across Cancer Treatments(IMPACT) Consortium by providing expert leadership logistical support and data coordination to the projectsimplementing methods to improve symptom management across the cancer treatment continuum and addressthe unique challenges of minority and medically underserved populations.

Project Title: The Nathan Schnaper Intern Program in Translational Cancer Research
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeSignificant progress in detection and treatment has reduced cancer mortality rates; however with over 1.7 millionnew cases and 600000 deaths from cancer reported in 2019 it remains a major health concern in the US.Advances in our understanding of fundamental biological mechanisms that promote oncogenesis haveprogressed at an unparalleled rate and provide a seedbed for the novel therapeutic interventions. The currentchallenge is to close this widening gap between laboratory discoveries and their clinical applications in the fightagainst cancer. Inspiring and training the next generation of cancer researchers and oncologists is central toaccelerate the translation of research breakthroughs into new diagnostics and therapeutics. Towards this goalthe Nathan Schnaper Intern Program in Translational Research at the University of Maryland GreenebaumComprehensive Cancer Center integrates research educational and clinical training components that build onits strong history to train the next generation of cancer researchers and oncologists.
Study Section: Institutional Training and Education Study Section (F)[NCI-F]

Project Title: A Data Resource for Blood and Marrow Transplants and Adoptive Cellular Therapy Research
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe Center for International Blood and Marrow Transplant Research (CIBMTR) plays a unique and importantrole in facilitating clinical research in hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HCT) and adoptive cellulartherapy (ACT). It is committed to developing its research database in volume and scope; its statisticalexpertise; and data sharing capabilities to meet the needs of investigators in a rapidly evolving field. Thisaward will allow CIBMTR to build on the infrastructure made possible by support from U24-CA076518 to betterserve the research and healthcare community and to address issues important to patients.

Project Title: Behavioral Activation for Depression in Older Adult Cancer Survivors: Pilot Randomized Control Trial and Implementation Outcomes
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEOlder adult cancer survivors (65 years 1-year post-treatment) are an understudied yet uniquely high-riskgroup for untreated depression in need of novel mental health treatments and delivery strategies across cancersettings. Despite the rapidly growing number of older adult cancer survivors no studies have evaluated theimplementation of evidence-baseddepression treatment for older adults through cancersurvivorship clinics. Thecurrent proposal adopts an implementation science framework to evaluate the preliminary efficacy andimplementation outcomes of social work delivered Behavioral Activation via telephone for older adult cancersurvivors with the ultimate goal of increasing engagement in evidence based depression treatment.

Project Title: Hypoglossal neuropathy in the pathogenesis of radiation associated dysphagia (hRAD)
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe incidence of highly curable head and neck cancers is rapidly rising and there are more long-term survivorsthan ever. Radiation treatment is very commonly given at doses sufficient to cause crippling late cranialneuropathy (nerve dysfunction) and dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) that can progress to the point that it resultsin a lifelong feeding tube or death from aspiration pneumonia even after cancer is cured. This application seeksto understand how abnormal nerve function in the tongue may be present and measured long before it is evidentin clinic hopefully to provide an earlier therapy target to help swallowing function before irreversible damage isdone.
Organization Name: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR

Project Title: Developing glycosylated RNAs as novel clinical targets for aggressive prostate cancer.
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEProstate Cancer is a serious health crisis in the United States and remains the second leading cause ofcancer-related male deaths despite implementation of new screening methods and therapeutic drugs forthis disease. Glycosylation involving the covalent attachment of carbohydrates onto proteins and lipidsis shown to impact their molecular stability cellular localization biological function and malignancy - butvirtually nothing is known about the new field of glycosylated RNAs (glycoRNAs) or their role in humandisease such as prostate cancer. Innovative/exploratory work described in this proposal employing aspectrum of human prostate cancer cell lines and an in vivo mouse model for prostate cancer willdrastically improve our understanding of glycoRNA mechanisms involved during prostate tumorprogression and lead to novel RNA-based biomarker and treatment strategies for lethal prostate cancer.

Project Title: Re-Engaging AYA Survivors in Cancer-Related Healthcare (REACH): A Sequential Multiple Assignment Randomized Trial (SMART)
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEAdolescent and young adult (AYA) survivors of childhood cancer are at risk for second cancers and otherchronic health conditions (so-called late effects) yet their engagement in long-term follow-up care declines asthey transition to adulthood and adult-oriented follow-up care. We aim to fill a significant knowledge gap bytesting an adaptive re-engagement intervention specifically targeting AYA who are not currently engaged infollow-up care and that aims to enhance appointment making attendance and self-management. The goal isto identify optimal intervention strategies to meet an AYAs individual needs for re-engagement in care andself-management ultimately reducing morbidities and health disparities in this population.
Study Section: Interdisciplinary Clinical Care in Specialty Care Settings Study Section[ICSC]

Project Title: The Boston Lung Cancer Survival Cohort
Public Health Relevance: The Boston Lung Cancer Survival cohort contains an extensive amount of valuable questionnaire and biologicdata that can be leveraged to extend our understanding of the natural history of lung cancer. The combinationof biomarkers tumor molecular characterization radiomic features and traditional epidemiologic risk factors inthis rich resource enables powerful translational research and provides unique opportunities to explore novelpredictors of overall survival and treatment outcomes. With continued support the Boston Lung CancerSurvival cohort can continue to advance our understanding of the molecular heterogeneity of lung cancerenabling effective diagnostic and therapeutic strategies that improve the health of individuals diagnosed withlung cancer.

Project Title: Cardiovascular Disease Risk Factors Cardiovascular Disease Risk Prediction and Genetics in the Million Veteran Program
Public Health Relevance: Most veterans will develop atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (CVD) during their lifetime.Research to date has largely focused on the role of traditional risk factors and the occurrence ofCVD outcomes. Genes and the environment work in concert to foster the development oftraditional risk factors and subsequently increase the risk for clinical vascular disease. Thisproject provides the opportunity to investigate the role of genes and environment as causative inthe development of the risk factors and the association of genes with CVD itself. It also expandsthe scope to include new CVD risk factors including blood cell indices inflammatory conditionsvalvular heart disease obstructive sleep apnea and atrial fibrillation. The project we describecreates the framework for the VA to participate in the process for CVD research concerningMVP assessment risk factors and CVD outcomes.

Project Title: Subcellular enzyme-instructed self-assembly for molecular anticancer nanomedicines
Public Health Relevance: Narrative The overall goal of this research is to develop innovative approaches for overcoming drug resistance incancer therapy. Developing nanomedicines by subcellular enzyme-instructed self-assembly (sEISA) toselectively kill cancer cells and to overcome the drug resistance this approach will ultimately lead to a newcancer therapy for millions of people who will need anticancer treatment in the future and thus improving healthof the Nation.

Project Title: Understanding Quality of Life and Physical Activity in Black Breast Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeDespite the improvements in breast cancer survival black women experience suboptimal quality of life whichis why it is important to evaluate their experiences to improve quality of life (QOL) and target healthy behaviorsthat foster a longer life among racial/ethnic minority breast cancer survivors. Physical activity (PA) is amodifiable behavior with the potential to help reduce racial disparities in QOL. This fellowship will help toestablish the relationship between PA and QOL among black women generate new knowledge and insights toenhance QOL among black women cultivate community partnerships and empower other researchers toincrease the representation of racial/ethnic minorities in studies focusing on behavioral medicine to meet theneeds of this community.
Organization Name: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL

Project Title: Examining Tobacco Use Relapse among Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEWhile many cancer survivors will quit using tobacco after receiving a cancer diagnosis many (13-60%) will goon to relapse due to reasons that are still not well understood. Intrapersonal factors (e.g. cancer worrynegative affect) and interpersonal factors (e.g. social support social constraint) may play a role but researchhas yet to examine their momentary or longitudinal influence on tobacco use relapse or risk of tobacco relapseamong cancer survivors. This F31 NRSA award will provide the support to complete the proposed projectwhich aims to examine these predictors relation to tobacco use relapse using multiple methodologies (i.e.ecological momentary assessment longitudinal survey) as well as provide the applicant with support toreceive advanced training needed to pursue an independent research career in cancer prevention and tobaccocontrol.

Project Title: Cancer Center Support Grant
Public Health Relevance: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVEThe UCLA Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center (JCCC) strategic mission is to accelerate discoveries thatprevent and cure cancer. Through a deep and broad spectrum of impactful research endeavors clinical andresearch education and training programs and the highest quality of patient care in multiple academic andcommunity settings the JCCC seeks to reduce the burden of cancer throughout its Los Angeles Countycatchment area and the nation.

Project Title: Predicting risk of cardiotoxicity among young and emerging adult breast cancer patients from treatment to survivorship
Public Health Relevance: Breast cancer is the most commonly occurring cancer among women globally while cardiovascular disease hasbecome a leading cause of death among breast cancer survivors. Commonly used breast cancer treatments areknown to cause cardiotoxicity but the majority of studies have not examined the growing population of young andemerging adult breast cancer patients. The objective of this study is to develop a personalized model ofpsychosocial factors traditional CVD risk factors and molecular markers that predicts risk of cardiotoxicityamong YEA breast cancer patients.
Study Section: NHLBI Mentored Clinical and Basic Science Study Section[MCBS(JA)]

Project Title: Living Beyond Cancer: How Distance Impacts Childhood Cancer Survivorship Care
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe proposed research is relevant to public health since it focuses on evaluating potential modifiable factors(distance to care and residential environment) for childhood cancer survivors to improve the quality ofsurvivorship care opportunities and later life health outcomes. Reducing barriers to survivorship careopportunities may improve the quality of life and life expectancy for childhood cancer survivors. Thus theproposed research is relevant to NCIs mission to support cancer research to advance scientific knowledge andhelp all people live longer healthier lives.

Project Title: Research and Education towards Solutions for Late effects to Innovate Excel and Nurture after chronic Graft-versus-Host Disease (RESILIENT after cGVHD)
Public Health Relevance: Project Narrative The overarching goal of the Research and Education towards Solutions for Late effectsto Innovate Excel and Nurture after chronic Graft-versus-Host Disease (RESILIENT aftercGVHD) consensus conference is to address the state of the science recommendations forclinical care and research priorities for pediatric survivors of Hematopoetic cell transplantation(HCT) diagnosed with cGVHD. The conference will be divided into four sections each led by aworking group: Phases of Chronic GVHD Organ Dysfunction and Immunity Metabolism Growthand Development and Patient Important Outcomes. Preliminary reports of the working groupswill be open for discussion over a one day conference for stakeholders on the HCT community.

Project Title: Examining Physical Activity Promotion Intervention Outcomes Barriers and Facilitators in Breast Cancer Survivors with Fatigue
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeCancer-related fatigue (CRF) is the most common and distressing long-term side effect of breast cancer diseaseand treatment. Physical activity is the first-line treatment recommended to reduce fatigue levels in breast cancersurvivors but no scalable tailored physical activity intervention designed to meet the specific needs of breastcancer survivors with CRF exist. The public health significance of this study lies in its potential to betterunderstand how to promote physical activity in BCS with CRF to inform future intervention development andultimately improve health outcomes and quality of life in this large and growing population.

Project Title: The role of amphiregulin in mediating radiation cystitis in cancer survivors
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVERadiation cystitis is a severely debilitating chronic fibrotic bladder condition that results from radiationtherapy for cancers in the pelvis for which no safe and effective treatment exists to date. Amphiregulin is apro-fibrotic protein that is highly expressed in the bladder after radiation therapy and thus we hypothesizethat amphiregulin mediates radiation-induced bladder fibrosis and can serve as a predictive marker forradiation cystitis. The successful outcomes of this study will determine if amphiregulin is a viable therapeutictarget for radiation-induced fibrosis which will also be relevant for other benign bladder conditionscharacterized by a fibrotic bladder.
Study Section: Kidney and Urological Systems Function and Dysfunction Study Section[KUFD]

Project Title: The Lymphoma Epidemiology of Outcomes (LEO) Cohort Study
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVENHL is the most common hematologic malignancy and there are many unmet clinical and public health needsof this growing patient population. The goal of this infrastructure grant is to support a cohort of over 16000non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) patients in order to address broad and cutting-edge research that identifiesclinical epidemiologic (including lifestyle and other exposures) host genetic tumor and treatment factors andthe interaction among these factors on short and long-term outcomes. These efforts will identify newapproaches to improve the survival and well-being of NHL patients.

Project Title: Technology-Enabled Activation of Skin Cancer Screening for Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation Survivors and their Primary Care Providers
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVEPatients who receive hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) to cure their cancers face elevated risks for skincancers in the future. We are testing which program best supports better and faster diagnosis of skin cancers:1) teaching patients to perform skin self-examination and talk to their doctors 2) teaching patients and theirdoctors to perform skin examinations or 3) teaching patients and their doctors to perform skin examinations anddoctors to take digital photographs for tele-dermatology support. We expect our results to improve detection ofskin cancer in HCT survivors and ultimately other high-risk cancer survivor populations.

Project Title: Targeted Therapies for Lymphoid Malignancies
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis competive renewal focuses on characterization of residual CLL cells and immune function of themicroenvironment after prolonged therapy with an irreversible Brutons tyrosine Kinase inhibitor (BTKi) eitheribrutinib and acalabrutinib. Additionally this project seeks to target these residual cells for elimination clinicallyusing novel immune based therapies such as VAY-736 to facilitate discontinuation strategies of BTKi withsignificant economic and survivorship benefit to patients with CLL.

Project Title: Racial disparities in advanced prostate cancer care: An analysis of treatment patterns and patient experience
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThough large racial disparities have been described in clinical prostate cancer outcomes there has beenlimited investigation into racial disparities of patient-centered outcomes specifically in patients with advancedprostate cancer the population experiencing the highest morbidity and mortality both from the cancer itself andits associated therapies. The proposed research aims to use data from approximately 1500 patients in theInternational Registry for Men with Advanced Prostate Cancer (IRONMAN) to quantify racial disparities intreatment patterns patient experience with the health care system and quality of life in patients with advancedprostate cancer in the United States and United Kingdom. This work will provide novel information on thespectrum of care received by patients with advanced prostate cancer and propose potential areas forintervention by health care providers towards decreasing racial disparities in prostate cancer mortality.

Project Title: Consumer-based meditation app Calm for treatment of sleep disturbance in hematological cancer patients
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeChronic hematological cancer (CHC) patients are characterized by long term and high symptom burdenincluding up to 65% reporting chronic sleep disturbances that are also often associated with inflammationfatigue and emotional distress (anxiety and depression). Meditation is an effective non-pharmacologic strategyto self-manage and improve cancer-related symptoms and mediation delivered via mobile applications mayaddress cancer patients barriers to in-person interventions (i.e. fatigue pain transportation schedulingdifficulties) without the time and expertise limitations of cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) andside effect risks from medication. This study is the first to test a commercially available smartphone-basedmeditation application to self-manage sleep disturbance inflammation fatigue and emotional distress (anxietydepression) among CHC patients and to explore the sustained effects of meditation compared to a healtheducation podcast control group.
Organization Name: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER
Study Section: Biobehavioral Mechanisms of Emotion, Stress and Health Study Section[MESH]

Project Title: Increasing physical activity among breast cancer survivors: Use of the ORBIT Model to refine and test a novel approach to exercise promotion based on affect-regulation
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis award supports the career development of Courtney J. Stevens PhD a clinical psychologist atDartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center whose long-term career goal is to become a leading investigator inbehavioral oncology and health behavior intervention science. The training and mentoring plan is designed toprovide knowledge and skills in early-phase intervention development intensive longitudinal data collection andanalysis methods randomized clinical trial design and professional development. The research componentfollows the Obesity-Related Behavioral Intervention Trials (ORBIT) Model in systematically developing anintervention that will be used in subsequent research to test the hypothesis that the affect-regulated exerciseprescription can promote clinically meaningful increases in moderate-vigorous physical activity among physicallyinactive breast cancer survivors.

Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe Childrens Oncology Group (COG) is the worlds largest organization devoted exclusively to childhood andadolescent cancer research. Project Title: Mechanism Underlying Sleep Disruption by Mammary Tumors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEBreast cancer is the most frequently diagnosed cancer in women. Advances in its detection andtreatment have substantially increased long-term survival among patients with breast cancerbut there is considerable individual variability in the progression of the disease and the extent towhich it dysregulates other important biological systems. The goal of the proposed research is todetermine how tumors alter sleep and metabolism which in turn can further compromise thehealth and well-being of breast cancer survivors.

Project Title: Enhancing Self Care Among Oral Cancer Survivors: The Empowered Survivor Trial
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeOral and oropharyngeal cancer survivors carry a high symptom burden that results in many self carerequirements that can be overwhelming complex difficult to manage and can result in compromised quality oflife unmet needs and low participation in self-care. There are no empirically based interventions to enhanceskills and confidence to manage oral cancer survivors self care. This study proposes to evaluate a promisingonline intervention called Empowered Survivor or ES for short and evaluate its impact on self efficacy inmanaging care preparedness for managing survivorship and health related quality of life as well asengagement in several key self-care behaviors. Should ES prove efficacious it will serve as a model of careand advance both science and practice for cancer survivors particularly those who reside in the community.
Study Section: Clinical Management of Patients in Community-based Settings Study Section[CMPC]

Project Title: Comprehensive Cancer Center Support Grant
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVE  DIRECTORS OVERVIEWThe O'Neal Comprehensive Cancer Center is committed to reducing the cancer burdens and cancer disparitiesin the State of Alabama. This is done through a basic science and population science strategic research planthat is developed with community engagement and focused on elucidating the risk factors and mechanisticunderpinnings of these cancer burdens and cancer disparities. The results of this work are then translatedthrough diagnostic and therapeutic clinical trials to impact cancer outcomes and behavioral interventions tomitigate cancer risks and improve the quality of life of cancer survivors in our catchment area.

Project Title: Cancer Center Support Grant
Public Health Relevance: OVERALL: DIRECTOR'S OVERVIEW & SIX ESSENTIAL CHARACTERISTICS PROJECT NARRATIVEThe Chao Family Comprehensive Cancer Center (CFCCC) of the University of California Irvine (UCI) is theonly academic cancer center based in Orange County the sixth most populous county in the United States withover 3.2 million residents who embody substantial socioeconomic and racial/ethnic diversity. Designated as acomprehensive cancer center by the National Cancer Institute since 1997 and backed by the research enterpriseof UCI a member of the Association of American Universities the CFCCC carries out research across thespectrum of cancer including fundamental mechanisms of cancer development novel modes of detection andimaging new anti-cancer drugs and devices and cancer susceptibility prevention and survivorship. Through itsresearch programs and supporting resources the CFCCC translates these discoveries through the pipeline intoclinical treatments and interventions that are directed specifically towards reducing the burden of cancer on themulti-ethnic population of Orange County and surrounding areas and advances this new knowledge onto a widerstage to change clinical cancer practice across the country.

Project Title: Early Identification of Childhood Cancer Survivors at High Risk for Late Onset Cardiomyopathy: An Artificial Intelligence Approach utilizing Electrocardiography
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeChildhood cancer survivors treated with anthracycline chemotherapy or chest-directed radiation are at risk forcardiomyopathy. This study aims to validate advanced artificial intelligence methods to accurately identifysurvivors at high risk for cardiomyopathy using low-cost accessible electrocardiography data and to evaluatethe feasibility of using smartwatches for this purpose. Such artificial intelligence tools may facilitate earlydetection of high risk survivors who may benefit from advanced cardiac imaging and interventions to preservecardiac function.

Project Title: Longitudinal study of cognitive remediation to prepare for transition of care in youth with sickle cell disease
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVECognitive impairment is a pervasive debilitating feature of sickle cell disease (SCD) with over 50% of childrendemonstrating early neurodevelopmental delays ultimately influencing ability for adolescents with SCD toengage in effective decision-making needed for successful transition into adulthood. This study will examine theefficacy of a cognitive remediation program (CRP) to improve decision-making skills in youth with SCD (10-18y)in order to enhance self-care and self-advocacy to improve and maintain transition readiness skills. This researchproposal will fill several major gaps in the understanding of remediation of cognitive deficits in SCD and will laythe groundwork for evidence-based interventions aimed to improve transition of care enhance self-care andultimately improve life expectancy.

Project Title: Long-Term Mental Health Outcomes in Prostate Cancer Survivors and Their Partners
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVEProstate cancer survivorship is common and increasing and may have substantial mental health impacts inpatients and their intimate partners that are understudied and preventable. This project will provide the firstlong-term assessment of mental health outcomes in prostate cancer survivors and their partners by integratinghighly complete data from primary care specialty outpatient and inpatient settings for a large population-based cohort. The results will identify the long-term mental health sequelae in prostate cancer survivors theirpartners and high-risk subgroups and guide early interventions to improve their long-term health.

Project Title: Cancer Center Support Grant
Public Health Relevance: OVERALL: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe Wake Forest Baptist Comprehensive Cancer Center (WFBCCC) in Winston-Salem North Carolina servesthe people of the Appalachian region (North Carolina Virginia and West Virginia) and is a nationally recognizedhub for clinical basic and population scientists focused on the prevention and early detection of cancerdeveloping novel cancer therapies and improving the health of cancer survivors. Through the support of the P30Cancer Center Support Grant WFBCCC provides research resources in support of its scientists with the goalof reducing the cancer burden regionally and nationally through cutting-edge research professional educationand community outreach and engagement.

Project Title: Novel Biomarkers for Cancer-Related Fatigue: Integrating Metabolomics Genomics and Behaviors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEFatigue is a persistent problem affecting up to 90% of cancer patients yet treatment options are limited.Advances in metabolomics and genomics offer an unprecedent opportunity to unravel the underlyingbiological mechanisms and to identify novel biomarkers of fatigue which may be targets for therapeuticintervention. We will use the 3-P (Predisposing Precipitating Prepetuating) model to combine genomicsmetabolomics inflammatory markers and behaviors to comprehensively examine contributors of cancer-related fatigue in ColoCare a large cohort of colorectal cancer patients.
Study Section: Cancer, Heart, and Sleep Epidemiology B Study Section[CHSB]

Project Title: Driving Rehabilitation and Innovation for Evaluating Risk in Post-Intensive Care Unit Survivors (DRIVE-PICS)
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVEOlder adults are at risk for ICU-acquired cognitive decline discernible from clinical biological and imaging-related changes in the brain following delirium and critical illness. Our Driving Rehabilitation and Innovation forEvaluating Risk in Post Intensive Care Unit Survivors (DRIVE-PICS) application seeks to implement in-vehiclekinematic driving data with neurocognitive assessments for essential formative work to develop data-basedinsights into driving behaviors. DRIVE-PICS is designed to contribute to a critical gap in health promotion todevelop an evidence-based in-vehicle driving assessment system to provide actionable driving safety data andrehabilitation strategies tailored to older ICU survivors their care partners and clinicians.
Study Section: Aging Systems and Geriatrics Study Section[ASG]

Project Title: Risk stratified survivorship care pathways for early-onset colorectal cancer
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis study will utilize large and diverse registry-based samples of patients with early-onset colorectal cancer toestimate the risk of recurrence associated with clinical and sociodemographic data and characterizesurveillance intensity and survivorship care needs across multiple domains using patient surveys. Using thesepopulation-based estimates of recurrence risk and patient care needs we will then engage with clinicianpatient and caregiver stakeholders to develop and evaluate a stratified survivorship care framework and carepathways to improve care for this understudied and growing population of patients.

Project Title: Improving Prognostication for Traumatic Brain Injury
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEFunctional and cognitive recovery after traumatic brain injury (TBI) is highly variable and poorly understood.Better TBI prognostic models are urgently needed for individual patient care and prognostic stratification forTBI clinical trials. This career development award led by Amelia W. Maiga MD MPH will (1) create a betterprognostic model with time-varying clinical data image-based biomarkers and TBI-specific biomarkers and(2) describe distinct trajectories of functional and cognitive recovery after hospitalized TBI.

Project Title: Assessing efficacy and implementation of an EHR tool to assess heart health among survivors
Public Health Relevance: Public Health RelevanceSurvivors of early-stage cancers are susceptible to cardiovascular disease due to pre-existingcardiovascular risk factors and receipt of potentially cardiotoxic cancer treatments. Our automatedelectronic health record (EHR)-based tool addresses the growing burden of cardiovascular disease amongcancer survivors in the United States by empowering oncologists to discuss cardiovascular health with theirpatients and facilitating appropriate care for cardiovascular disease risk factors. In this study we will testwhether our pragmatic EHR-based cardiovascular health tool  which incorporates patient risk factor andcancer treatment data  will improve cardiovascular health discussion completed visits and cardiovascularrisk factors in a real-world setting with the ultimate goal of improving cancer survivors' morbidity andmortality.1

Project Title: CAPRI: Columbia Cancer Research Training Program for Resident-Investigators
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeDue to the rapid nature of innovation in cancer research challenges exist in training and retaining physician-scientists conducting rigorous translational research. The Columbia Cancer Research Training Program forResident-Investigators (CAPRI) addresses the critical shortage of well-trained cancer physicians from multipledisciplines. The continuation of CAPRI which provides comprehensive research training will ensure a cadre offuture clinical investigators who will conduct high-impact research spanning the cancer care continuum.

Project Title: P53 DNA Repair Imbalance and Immune Response in Breast Cancer Mortality Disparities
Public Health Relevance: NarrativeBlack women have higher breast cancer mortality and different prevalence of key DNA repair pathwaymutations notably p53. These DNA repair pathways may interact with other mechanisms of treatmentresistance including immune responses. This project will elucidate the relationship between p53 DNA repairmechanisms and immune response and evaluate the implications of these pathways for mortality disparities.

Project Title: Decreasing Polypharmacy in Older Adults with Curable Cancers
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEPolypharmacy or taking multiple concurrent medications is very common in older adults with cancerundergoing curative-intent chemotherapy. Polypharmacy is associated with adverse outcomes includingreceiving less chemotherapy which in turn can affect cancer-related survival. Deprescribing or the planneddiscontinuation of medications is an intervention that can address polypharmacy but it has not been studied inolder adults with cancer receiving curative-chemotherapy; this proposal refines and tests two deprescribingintervention strategies in these patients.

Project Title: Psychobiological stress vulnerability executive control and emotion regulation in children and adolescents with cancer
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeFindings from this study may ultimately enable providers in pediatric oncology to discern via simple pen-and-paper screening information about a child's immune response to stress and related risk for psychosocial orneurocognitive deficits linked to impairment in emotion regulation. In this way both psychosocial interventionstargeted at improving emotion regulation or neurocognition could be combined with immune-targetedpharmacological interventions in a true model of child-centered precision medicine. Given that eventual long-term survivorship is anticipated for more than 85% of pediatric oncology patients understanding the nature andlong-term psychological and biological impact of stress in pediatric cancer is critical for enabling maximalquality of life into young adulthood and beyond.

Project Title: Modeling Multi-Source Data in Hodgkin Lymphoma
Public Health Relevance: Narrative:Despite therapeutic advances in Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL) adverse effects of treatment can manifest as earlyas within one year after treatment and result in considerable morbidity altered health-related quality of life andexcess mortality. Through an unprecedented worldwide collaboration of adult oncology HL expertsepidemiologists statisticians imaging experts and decision scientists we have harmonized modern multi-source HL data from seminal international clinical trials and prominent HL registries that will be harnessed viasimulation models for translation to clinical use. Our three-step approach (predictive modeling to multi-statemodeling to simulation/decision modeling) will be designed to incorporate future prospective data as new/noveltreatments and knowledge emerges over time and this projects results will be significant as they will delineateacute & post-acute outcomes for individual HL patients and inform development of models & paradigms for otherdiseases.
Study Section: Clinical Data Management and Analysis Study Section[CDMA]

Project Title: Kappa opioid and oxytocin interactions in social buffering and separation
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeSocial relationships are crucially important to human health; however we do not fully understand what in ourbrains drives us to form relationships to feel loss when the relationships end or to allow our partners to reduceour stress levels (also called social buffering). In this project we will study titi monkeys which form adult pairbonds using imaging and drug manipulations to examine the neurobiology of social buffering and separation.

Project Title: Assessing the effect of virtual navigation interventions to improve health insurance literacy and decrease financial burden:  A CCSS randomized trial
Public Health Relevance: In response to the RFA-CA-20-027 we propose to conduct a Type 1 hybrid effectiveness-implementation trialto assess the effectiveness of a 4-session synchronous digital health insurance navigation interventioncompared to 1) enhanced usual care and 2) an asynchronous delivery of the digital health insurancenavigation intervention in promoting health insurance literacy among 520 survivors from the Childhood CancerSurvivor Study (survivors diagnosed before the age of 21). A rigorous implementation evaluation will beconducted which will leverage our objective to establish a sustainable intervention to improve health outcomesof childhood cancer survivors through enhanced health insurance literacy and decreased financial hardship.

Project Title: Social Health Activity Behaviors and Quality of Life among Young Adult Cancer Survivors: A Longitudinal Study
Public Health Relevance: NarrativeSocial challenges are a major issue for young adult cancer patients (18-39 years old). Impairments in socialrelationships referred to as social health may decrease physical activity after a cancer diagnosis leading topoorer quality of life after treatment and recovery. This study will investigate the relationships between socialhealth physical activity and quality of life to expand our understanding of their interrelations to informintervention strategies to foster healthy survivorship for young adult cancer patients.

Project Title: Training clinical providers in evidence-based hypnosis for cancer pain management
Public Health Relevance: In 2019 over 1.7 million Americans will be diagnosed with cancer and among theinnumerable rigors associated with the diagnosis and its treatment perhaps the greatest sourceof suffering is pain. Hypnosis has been shown to be a clinically efficacious and cost-effectivenonpharmacologic intervention for pain but few cancer care providers are trained in its use. Thegoal of the proposed R25E is to train cancer care providers in hypnosis to manage pain acrossthe cancer continuum so that providers may skillfully and competently deliver hypnosis toreduce the pain burden of their patients.

Project Title: Identifying the Role of Serotonergic Signaling in the Maturation ofDendritic Spines
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVECognitive disabilities such as those observed in developmental disorders like Autism are often marked byimproper synaptic connections between neurons. Although there are clear links between abnormal synapticdevelopment and behavioral deficits persisting into adulthood the specific cellular and molecular mechanismsthat underly these deficits are not well understood. Disbalances of the neuromodulator serotonin have beenassociated with improper circuit formation in the brain and an increased likelihood of developing cognitivedisabilities; characterizing the role of serotonin in proper synaptic development will help further our understandingof the cellular and molecular etiologies of developmental disorders.

Project Title: Centralized Pain Management In Older Adult Cancer Survivors

It is imperative that we determine the effect of age on centralized pain quantifyits management and improve upon the care of older adult cancer survivors with pain.

Project Title: Trajectory of epigenetic aging and health outcomes in childhood cancer survivors
Public Health Relevance: RELEVANCESurvivors of childhood cancer experience accelerated aging with high burden of chronic health conditions (CHC)and premature mortality hence it is critical to conduct proposed clinical aging research in this vulnerablepopulation to improve survivorship care and quality of life for these individuals. In the current proposal we willleverage preexisting epigenetic profiling data and also generate additional epigenetic profiling data from storedbiospecimens collected during the longitudinal follow-up of our well-established cohort of childhood cancersurvivors as well as from samples collected during two ongoing health promoting behavioral intervention trials.We will investigate how social determinants of health and health behaviors will affect the change of epigeneticage acceleration (EAA) among survivors of childhood cancer and how the change in EAA will subsequentlyinfluence long-term health outcomes and explore the effect of health promoting behavioral interventions on EAAand if the change pattern of EAA portends the improvement of targeted health outcomes.
Study Section:
Aging, Injury, Musculoskeletal, and Rheumatologic Disorders Study 
Section[AIMR]

Project Title: A multi-level examination of the influences of racism on cancer pain equity
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEPain is a common and disabling symptom of cancer yet patients of color are half as likely as White patients toreceive adequate pain management likely because they are prescribed fewer and less potent opioids. Thisproposal will examine the scope and key drivers of racial and ethnic disparities in opioid management acrossthe cancer care trajectory using a multi-level analysis of Medicare and Medicaid claims data linked tocomprehensive information about physicians practices systems and neighborhoods. Findings will elucidatekey mechanisms by which racism undermines equitable pain management and will be used to design ascalable multi-level intervention to promote equitable cancer pain management.
Study Section: Organization and Delivery of Health Services Study Section[ODHS]

Project Title: The development of a technology-based information support intervention (iSupport) among patients with differentiated thyroid cancer post radioactive iodine therapy
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativePeople who are diagnosed with thyroid cancer often receive radioactive iodine therapy. This therapy can leadto many symptoms that patients did not expect. Patients also report difficulty managing these symptoms. Thefirst goal of this project is to develop a web-based intervention that provides information and support topatients with thyroid cancer who receive radioactive iodine therapy. The second goal is to test if theintervention reduces patient symptom burden.

Project Terms: Childhood;Hematology;Oncology;Training Programs
Project Title: Pediatric Training Program Hematology and Oncology
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis program is designed to train the next generation of leaders in pediatric hematology-oncology biomedicalscience. The focus is on providing a strong guidance and mentoring around investigations pertaining to areasof clinical and basic research at the forefront of pediatric hematology-oncology including but not limited togenomics epigenomics developmental biology cellular therapies clinical trial design and survivorship.Qualified trainees both MDs and MD/PhDs will be selected for their potential to assume academicpositions in pediatric departments at major medical schools. The training program compliments multipleother existing training programs in the Department of Pediatrics and the Washington University School ofMedicine.

Project Title: Impact of Obesity on Chemotherapy-Induced Cytotoxicity: Immune Cells and Skeletal Muscle
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe prevalence of obesity continues to increase in the US and obesity increases the risk of cancer. While it iscommon practice to apply a dosing cap current recommendations for the treatment of obese cancer patients isfull body surface area chemotherapy dosing regimens despite some evidence suggesting that these patientsmay have exacerbated drug toxicities. Given that obese individuals are more likely to undergo anti-cancertreatments there is a need for studying the complex over-lap between obesity and cancer; my proposed studywill examine the mechanisms underlying obesitys impact on the off-target toxicities associated withchemotherapy.
Organization Name: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA

Project Title: Telerehabilitation for Veteran Lung Cancer Survivors Following Curative Intent Therapy
Public Health Relevance: Lung cancer is the second-most commonly diagnosed cancer among U.S. Veterans. Significant advanceshave been made in screening and treatment of lung cancer. Longevity following lung cancer has increased.After lung cancer treatment however many Veterans experience losses in functional capacity and increasedsymptoms. Rehabilitation services are needed to address these health issues. This project seeks to betterunderstand Veteran lung cancer survivors health goals following treatment knowledge and outcomeexpectations for exercise and rehabilitation and feelings towards technology to guide rehabilitation services. Itwill also test a telerehabilitation intervention with Veterans after lung cancer treatment with goals to improvetheir function and quality of life. This project will advance knowledge on strategies to better meet therehabilitation needs of Veteran lung cancer survivors. It will also develop the career of a physician researcherto acquire expertise in rehabilitation services for many Veteran lung cancer survivors.
Organization Name: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM

Project Title: Probabilistic Deep Learning Cervical Lymph-Node Auto-Segmentation For Imaging-enhanced Evaluation of Extracapsular Extension Risk (PDL-CLASIFIER)
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEClinical decision support tools for oropharyngeal cancer (OPC) using diagnostic imaging and clinical data havethe potential to improve metastatic cervical lymph node auto-segmentation and extracapsular nodal extensiondetection which could subsequently guide actionable treatment planning for improved efficacy with minimalside effects. We propose novel probabilistic deep learning methods that can simultaneously detect segmentand classify of metastatic lymph nodes using pretreatment multi-modality imaging and clinical data with patient-specific probabilistic estimation of segmentation and classification accuracy. These advancements wouldimprove public health by enhancing the accuracy of the risk stratification of OPC patients for appropriatetreatments ultimately improving treatment outcomes and quality of life of OPC survivors.
Organization Name: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR

Project Title: Harnessing Exercise to Enhance Immunity and Boost Immunotherapy Outcomes in Patients with Lung Cancer
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEOnly 15-25% patients with lung cancer respond to immunotherapy while more than two thirds of patientsexperience its side effects. Exercise training yields various physiological changes that can help improve immunefunction and has the great potential to improve immunotherapy outcomes and reduce its side effects. This multi-level clinical research will explore the mechanisms and efficacy of exercise on immune function and treatment-related outcomes and side effects in patients with lung cancer receiving immunotherapy which will provideinsights of the roles of exercise in immuno-oncology settings and ultimately to improve long-term cancersurvivorship in this patient population who are vulnerable yet understudied.

Project Title: The Carolina Endometrial Cancer Study: A population-based survivor cohort
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVEMore than 891000 U.S. women have an endometrial cancer history making it the second largest cancersurvivor group among women. Racial disparities have been reported across the endometrial cancercontinuumfrom recognition of symptoms leading to diagnosis through receipt of guideline recommendedcancer therapy and survivorship care. The Carolina Endometrial Cancer Study is a diverse population-basedcancer epidemiology survivor cohort that collects detailed information on novel molecular characteristics;medical history; cancer treatment and follow-up care; individual- and contextual-level social determinants ofhealth; and behavioral and lifestyle factors to advance our understanding of endometrial cancer survivorship.
Organization Name: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL

Project Title: Integration of multi-omics to predict and evaluate response during optimization of a nutrition intervention for cancer survivors with overweight and obesity
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe public health significance of this study lies in its potential to develop an improved understanding of thecomponents of lifestyle interventions that are necessary to help adult cancer survivors with overweight andobesity improve dietary patterns to reduce weight and improve cardiometabolic health. Results will lead tooptimized interventions that balance effectiveness with affordability scalability and efficiency to improve clinicalimplementation. These findings coupled with integration and interpretation of multi-omic assessments to predictand evaluate response will address a growing need for translational science that can result in more effectivenutrition interventions for this population and ultimately advance survivorship care and move the field towardprecision health.

Project Title: The ASPIRES Study: Activating Cancer Survivors and their Primary Care Providers to Increase Colorectal Cancer Screening
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVESecondary to the therapies that cured childhood cancer survivors most will develop a chronic disease early inlife. For example survivors treated with abdominal or pelvic radiation are at significantly elevated risk ofcolorectal cancer (CRC) at a young age. The proposed study aims to reduce the morbidity and mortality facedby these survivors by testing a remote intervention aimed at promoting early CRC screening and detection.
Study Section: Psychosocial Risk and Disease Prevention Study Section[PRDP]

Project Title: Reverse engineering cancer cachexia: muscle ribosome biogenesis in the etiology of cachexia
Public Health Relevance: NarrativeSkeletal muscle wasting during cancer cachexia has been long deemed to be a mere reflection of overall bodydegradation. Challenging this assumption we generated a mouse model that phenocopied cancer cachexiafrom within the skeletal muscle by impairing ribosome biogenesis the synthesis of new ribosomes specificallyin skeletal muscle. This proposal seeks to determine the etiology of cancer cachexia by interrogating thisintrinsic mechanism in skeletal muscle that leads to muscle wasting and cachectic phenotype.

Project Title: Clinical and genetic risk factors associated with adverse long-term health outcomes after curative therapies in individuals with sickle cell disease
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVEOur primary goal is to delineate adverse long-term health outcomes after curative therapies in children and adultswith sickle cell disease (SCD). Despite the recent success of curing sickle cell disease there have been limitedsystematic efforts to elucidate long-term health outcomes. Ultimately the shortened lifespan of young adults withSCD attributable to declining heart lung and kidney function for which curative therapies were designed toaddress must be measured against favorable and unfavorable late outcomes (mortality and morbidity) of thesetherapies.
Other PI or Project Leader(s): FITZHUGH, COURTNEY D; FRIEDMAN, DEBRA L.; PECKER, LYDIA
