Project Title: Research Into Visual Endpoints and RB Health Outcomes After Treatment:  The RIVERBOAT Consortium
Public Health Relevance: PUBLIC HEALTH STATEMENTTo preserve eyes with useful vision and to reduce therapy-related long-term morbidity and mortality (oculareffects subsequent malignancies psychosocial and cognitive dysfunction) retinoblastoma therapy haschanged dramatically over the past two decades replacing enucleation and external beam radiotherapy withsystemic chemotherapy local ophthalmic therapies and regionally administered chemotherapy andradiotherapy. The proposed research will define short and long-term outcomes of these newer therapiesidentify biologic correlates of advanced disease presentation which influence initial therapy choice and createa fully clinically annotated biorepository for genomic research. With virtually 100% survival this is the time toexamine the balance of efficacy and toxicity of contemporary therapy and to understand the biologicdeterminants of disease presentation.
Study Section: Cancer, Heart, and Sleep Epidemiology A Study Section[CHSA]

Project Title: A mixed methods approach to examining decisional needs and contextual factors influencing fertility status assessment outcomes among young female survivors of childhood cancer.
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVESurvivors of childhood cancer are at risk for treatment-related infertility and potential infertility is associated withdistress and poorer quality of life. The purpose of this study is to explore the perceived reproductive health needsof young adult female cancer survivors and to identify decisional and contextual factors that influence pursuit offertility status assessment using a sequential explanatory mixed method design. Findings from this study willcontribute to the testing of developmentally informed reproductive health and fertility-related psychoeducationaland decisional support interventions among young cancer survivors.

Project Title: Treatment-specific genetic risk scores for late effects prediction in childhoodadolescent and young adult cancer survivors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEPredicting risks for various chronic health conditions based on both cancer treatment exposures and hostfactors including genetic factors is critical for clinical decision-making in caring for survivors of childhoodadolescent and young adult cancer. The proposed project aims to develop a novel analytic method to modifytraditional polygenic risk scores i.e. individual scores quantifying genetic risk for disease based on resultsfrom genetic association studies so that these risk scores account for established genetic risk signals seen inlarge general population studies and the modifying effects of specific cancer therapies. The proposed project isrelevant to public health as it formulates new treatment-specific genetic risk predictors that can ultimatelyenhance plans for individualized care (e.g. informing screening frequencies/modalities andprevention/intervention strategies) for survivors at greatest risk for developing late effects.

Project Title: Multi-site adaptive trial of a technology-based EHR-integrated physical activity intervention in breast and endometrial cancer survivors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVE THE PARENT GRANT APPLICATIONDespite the documented importance of physical activity for cancer survivorship a large proportion of breastand endometrial cancer survivors remain physically inactive. In contrast to the one size fits all approach usedby most previous physical activity interventions for cancer survivors this trial will test an adaptive interventionapproach that reserves the most resources and support for women who do not fare well with a lower-costminimal intervention. The results from this trial will inform the development of scalable physical activityinterventions for breast and endometrial cancer survivors.

Project Title: Sleep Treatment Education Program-1 (STEP-1): A Randomized Trial of a Self-Management Insomnia Intervention for Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeDespite overwhelming evidence supporting behavioral treatment for insomnia it remains unavailable tomillions of cancer survivors whose chronic insomnia goes untreated. To address this need we propose to testSTEP-1 an online educational intervention delivered by a trained presenter. By reducing the barriers toevidence-based treatment STEP-1 has the potential to make effective insomnia treatment widely available forsurvivors and to significantly improve their health and quality of life.
Study Section: Lifestyle Change and Behavioral Health Study Section[LCBH]

Project Title: Precision Lung Cancer Survivorship Care Intervention: A Randomized Controlled Trial Serving Rural Survivors and Communities
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVELung cancer is the leading cause of cancer mortality in the nation and the burden of the illness isdisproportionally experienced by individuals residing in rural areas and experiencing economic challenges.Recent advances in early detection and treatment of lung cancer foretell significant reductions in lung cancermortality engendering a need for research efforts to inform lung cancer survivorship care guidelines. Thisresearch outlines a randomized clinical trial of a precision lung cancer survivorship care intervention aimed atimproving quality of life among rural lung cancer survivors within socioeconomically distressed areas in the US.

Project Title: Brain Health in Breast Cancer Survivors: Interaction of Menopause and Endocrine Therapy
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEAnti-estrogen endocrine therapies are widely used as adjuvant therapy for breast cancer with only limitedresearch on their risks to cognition and brain health in women. We will conduct a study of cognitive health inbreast cancer survivors on endocrine therapy comparing them to age and menopausal status matched healthycontrols to improve our understanding of whether endocrine therapies pose a risk to brain health. This researchprogram will apply highly sensitive task-related fMRI measures to assess these effects - advancing the PIstraining in key neuroimaging methods to launch her research program on brain health in cancer survivorship.

Project Title: Cancer Registry for Understanding and Improving Survivorship Experiences (CRUISE)
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeThe long-term goal of this research is to improve the use and effectiveness of survivorship care plans fordiverse underserved patient populations. This project leverages population-based cancer registries to take acomprehensive multi-level approach to examining the implementation of and patient experiences withsurvivorship care plans in breast and colorectal cancer survivors. Promising solutions will be developed in theform of best practice strategies that will re-envision the nature and delivery of survivorship care plans.
Study Section: Health Services Organization and Delivery Study Section[HSOD]

Project Title: The Role of ICU Delirium and Vascular Risk Factors in the Development of Post-ICU Cognitive Impairment and Dementia
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEPatients with delirium are at higher risk to develop subsequent mild cognitive impairment orAlzheimer's disease and other related dementias (ADRD). Patients hospitalized in the intensivecare unit (ICU) may represent a model cohort to more deeply understand the connectionbetween delirium and ADRD because they are at high risk for developing both disorders. Thisproject will examine the role of ICU delirium cardiovascular risk factors and post-ICUdepression in the development of subsequent cognitive impairment and ADRD in ICU deliriumsurvivors.

Project Terms: Aging;Health;Woman;improved;men
Project Title: Improving the Health of Aging Women and Men.
Public Health Relevance: NarrativeThe worlds population is aging rapidly with an expected 84 million American ages 65 and older by 2050. Thepurpose of this T32 program is to prepare doctoral students and postdoctoral fellows from a variety ofdisciplines in the health sciences to produce the evidence that will guide optimum efficient and cost-effectivehealth care and public health practices for diverse populations of aging women and men across the life course.The program is organized around 6 major research areas: 1) the study of sex and gender differences; 2) earlylife predictors of later life outcomes; 3) menopause and midlife; 4) healthy aging in mind and body; 5) chronicdisease multiple morbidity and survivorship; and 6) health disparities and vulnerable populations.

Project Title: Effects of dietary restriction in a new invertebrate model for sex-specific aging
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeDietary restriction is an increasingly popular intervention to enhance health and lifespan withbenefits believed to involve improvement in mitochondrial function. This pilot study seeks toestablish dietary restriction conditions that extend lifespan in Tigriopus californicus a newinvertebrate model for aging. Once conditions are optimized future work will leverage theunusual features of the species to assess sex differences in mitochondrial response to dietrestriction.
Study Section: Cellular Mechanisms in Aging and Development Study Section[CMAD]

Project Title: Ostomy Telehealth Self-management Training for Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: Typical post-operative care does not adequately prepare cancer survivors for ostomy self-managementbehavior change psychological support or healthy living which is necessary to assure optimal Health-RelatedQuality of Life. This chronic care-based Ostomy Self-Management Telehealth program led by ostomy nursesand peer ostomates is a patient/caregiver education and support program delivered via telehealth. Telehealthimproves ability to participate especially for cancer survivors with ostomies living in rural and other nonmetroareas.

Project Title: Impact of Chemotherapy on Bladder Function in Children
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEChildren with cancer are often treated with chemotherapy that while curative may cause long term side effects.We are investigating the effects on bladder function of two specific chemotherapies vincristine anddoxorubicin which are known to cause neurotoxicity and myotoxicity respectively. Surveying children treatedwith these agents for symptoms of bladder dysfunction and studying bladder physiology in a murine model ofvincristine and doxorubicin exposure will allow us to take the first steps in understanding chemotherapy-induced pediatric bladder dysfunction.
Study Section: Kidney, Urologic and Hematologic Diseases D Study Section[DDK-D]

Project Title: Enhancing Health Cost Literacy and Financial Capability among Young Adult Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeIndividuals treated for cancer during adolescence and young adulthood face significant financial burdens as aresult of their cancer treatment. These burdens known as financial toxicity have been shown to yield anegative impact on young adult survivors quality of life and their engagement with necessary cancersurvivorship care. The proposed study aims to fill a gap in the public health literature by developing and pilot-testing a novel intervention to address financial capability and health cost literacy factors known to influencefinancial toxicity at the patient-level.

Project Title: African Breast Cancer - Disparities in Outcomes - Plus (ABC-DO Plus)
Public Health Relevance: Project narrativeIn sub-Saharan Africa short-term breast cancer survival rates are relatively low but five-yearand longer-term survival and survivorship have not been comprehensively studied. In theAfrican Breast Cancer-Disparities in Outcomes (ABC-DO) study a five-country sub-SaharanAfrican prospective study of over 2100 women with breast cancer we have confirmedunacceptably low survival rates compared to those in high-income countries however we havealso found that survival rates differs between settings and in the first 2 years after diagnosisoutcomes are much more favorable in the growing number of women being diagnosed at earlierstages. We now propose to extend ABC-DO to examine for the first time in sub-Saharan Africafive-year survival and its socioeconomic clinical and biological determinants as well aslongitudinal changes in health related quality of life.
Organization Name: INTERNATIONAL AGENCY FOR RES ON CANCER

Project Title: Predictive Analytics in Hemodialysis: Enabling Precision Care for Patient with ESKD
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVEEnd stage kidney disease (ESKD) is a complex disease with individuals having variable life-expectancies. However there are no tools to reliably forecast individual life expectancy. In thisproposal we will develop an analytic framework for predicting patient life-expectancy allowing forthe personalized study and and ultimately treatment of individuals with ESKD.

Project Title: Culturally adapted mobile treatment of chronic pain in adolescent survivors of pediatric bone sarcoma
Public Health Relevance: NARRATIVEThis study will evaluate the impact of culturally adapted mobile cognitive behavioral therapy and transcranialdirect current stimulation on pain intensity and functional disability in a racially/ethnically and geographicallydiverse sample of adolescent survivors of bone sarcoma with chronic pain. Results will inform standard of carefor survivors of childhood cancer as few efficacious non-pharmacologic interventions are available andaccessible particularly for underserved survivors.

Project Title: Longitudinal investigation of sociocultural and behavioral influences on symptom management biological response and functioning between Chinese and White breast cancer survivors.
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis longitudinal prospective study will investigate the dynamics of sociocultural psychological and behavioral(e.g. diet and exercise) influences on biological response functional and symptom outcomes among ChineseAmerican and non-Hispanic White breast cancer survivors. Biological dietary and survey data will be collectedat three time points to examine whether 1) there are racial differences in study outcomes across time 2) outcomedifferences are mediated by different psychosocial and behavioral pathways and 3) mediational pathways aremoderated by race and acculturation level. In-depth individual interviews with a subset of the participants will beconducted in the fourth year of this study to grasp sociocultural and behavioral causes of the pathways in orderto develop individually and culturally appropriate interventions to promote cancer survivorship outcomes.
Study Section: Clinical Management of Patients in Community-based Settings Study Section[CMPC]

Project Title: Exploring Age Differences in Patient Reported Cognitive Function Trajectories among Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant and Chimeric Antigen Receptor T-cell patients and Linking Two Key Measures
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEOlder adults are increasingly being treated with Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HCT) withsimilar promise in chimeric antigen receptor T-cell (CAR-T) therapy yet little is known about potentialpatient reported outcomes (PRO) differences for older patients particularly cognitive function which hasshown to impact older HCT patients significantly more compared to younger. The current researchproposes to establish confidence in validity of measures assessing cognitive function assess agedifferences in cognitive function after HCT and CAR-T and explore trajectory patterns of cognitivefunction and other PROs by race/ethnicity and socioeconomic status in older HCT and CAR-T patients.The proposed research will produce evidence of construct validity for cognitive function measures usedin a national HCT and CAR-T registry link scores of two dominant measures of perceived cognitivefunction and provide novel description of HCT and CAR-T PRO trajectories.
Study Section: Neurological, Aging and Musculoskeletal Epidemiology Study Section[NAME]

Project Title: Facilitating Comprehensive Self and Proxy Symptom Assessments for Children with Cancer
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeChildren with cancer suffer from symptoms related to their diagnosis and cancer-directed treatments;symptoms that are frequently poorly recognized and may be under-treated by clinicians. Improving symptomassessment for children with cancer will enhance clinicians ability to track and manage symptoms to identifysymptom trends and could prevent the early termination of cancer treatments due to poorly managed drugtoxicities. The overall objective of this application is to refine and pilot test a method for comprehensive selfand parent symptom assessment for children with cancer.
Organization Name: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON

Project Title: Development and Validation of a Patient-Reported Measure Assessing Chimeric Antigen Receptor (CAR) T-Cell Therapy-Related Side Effects
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEChimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy is leading to a growing population of survivors worldwide whoare dealing with its unique and novel side effects. Current studies focus almost exclusively on physician-reportedadverse events on clinical trials; few have examined patient-reported side effects. The current study will developand validate a measure to assess patient-reported side effects associated with CAR T-cell therapy which willprovide important data regarding the patient experience and can contribute clinically to improved supportive carefor CAR T-cell therapy recipients.

Project Title: Creating Peace:  community-based youth violence prevention to address racism and discrimination
Public Health Relevance: This community-partnered study will examine via a cluster-randomized controlled trial the effectiveness of atrauma-focused gender-transformative youth violence prevention program that integrates racism and discrimi-nation prevention. Set in 24 neighborhoods in Pittsburgh Pennsylvania with concentrated social and economicdisadvantage this study addresses gender and racial injustice through a series of group discussions bringingtogether adolescents ages 14-18 with law enforcement officers in a process of social restoration. In addition toexamining the impact on youth violence perpetration the study will explore the impact of bias-based discrimi-nation prevention on law enforcement officers' attitudes and practices.

Project Title: Accelerated biological aging in breast cancer and risk for cognitive and physical complaints
Public Health Relevance: Relevance to public healthUnderstanding the role of biological aging in predicting cognitive and physical health outcomes in cancersurvivors has implications for future interventions designed to mitigate morbidity associated with thesebiomarker risk profiles in breast cancer patients. Together these data will guide the management andprevention of adverse lasting symptoms impacting quality of life in breast cancer survivors.
Study Section: Clinical Management of Patients in Community-based Settings Study Section[CMPC]

Project Title: Understanding the impact of the Affordable Care Act on healthcare coverage utilization and outcomes for childhood cancer survivors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVELacking health insurance coverage is a key barrier to accessing needed health care for adult-aged survivors ofchildhood cancer. This study will provide the first evidence of how the Affordable Care Act Medicaid expansionaffects insurance coverage and utilization of health care concordant with survivorship guidelines as well as theassociated downstream changes in late mortality for adult survivors of childhood cancer. This study will informfuture policy interventions aimed at increasing access as a means to reduce late effects related morbidity andmortality for this high-risk population.

Project Title: Self-Management of Adolescent and Young Adult Survivors of Childhood Cancer
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeAdolescent and young adult (AYA) survivors of childhood cancer represent a growing and underservedpopulation at risk for second cancers and other chronic health conditions (so-called late effects) despitethe vast resources used to cure them. As their risk for cancer late effects increases their engagement inlong-term follow-up care declines leaving them lost to follow-up and physically and psychologicallyvulnerable. We aim to fill a significant knowledge gap by prospectively studying AYA self-managementrelated to engagement in long- term follow-up care among AYA transitioning to adulthood elucidatingpredictors and patterns of self- management over time.

Project Title: A Motion Exergaming Approach to Promote Self-Managing Fatigue and Pain after Head and Neck Cancer Treatment
Public Health Relevance: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE:Fatigue and pain are two high incident symptoms threatening survivals among head and neck cancer patientsafter their treatment. For 6 weeks the intervention group will receive a home-based Physical Activityintervention with fitness graded Motion Exergames (PAfitME) and the attention control group will receive NCI-based survivorship education and exergame equipment. We will test whether or not PAfitME is effective toimprove fatigue musculoskeletal pain functional status and QOL during the critical transition period from thetreatment endpoint to self-management at home.
Study Section: Behavioral Medicine, Interventions and Outcomes Study Section[BMIO]

Project Title: Controlling Arbovirus Transmission: PopulationSuppression and Virus-Induced Mosquito Death
Public Health Relevance: Aedes aegypti is the main vector of dengue yellow fever and Zika viruses in both Brazil and the U.S. with recentoutbreaks of local transmission in Texas and Florida. The release of sterile mosquitoes can potentially suppressvector populations but current approaches are not ideal. Our proposal seeks to develop an improved conditionalsterility system in the dengue mosquito for use in public health vector control programs in both Brazil and theU.S.

Project Title: Cognitive impairment associated with androgen deprivation therapy for prostate cancer
Public Health Relevance: Cognitive impairment is a serious problem for prostate cancer survivors receiving androgen deprivationtherapy (ADT) for which there is currently no satisfactory treatment. In this project we will study the neuralmechanisms underlying the cognitive impairment caused by ADT in rats in order to identify potentially newtargets for intervention. We will specifically test the potential efficacy of vortioxetine a new antidepressant witha unique pharmacology that has been shown to improve cognitive impairment in depression and investigatethe mechanisms by which it may improve cognition after ADT. The results of this project may thus identify newstrategies to treat cognitive impairment after ADT and improve the quality of life for prostate cancer survivors.
Organization Name: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCIENCE CENTER

Project Title: Men Moving Forward: A Lifestyle Intervention for African American Prostate Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: NarrativeAfrican-American prostate cancer survivors are challenged by significant disparities in prostate cancer specificand overall mortality and quality of life. Although lifestyle interventions report beneficial results for PCsurvivors the inclusion of AA men is critically limited. We will examine the efficacy of Men Moving Forward alifestyle intervention on body composition behavior patient reported outcomes and biomarkers of generalhealth and prostate cancer progression.

Project Title: Small-molecule therapy for metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer
Public Health Relevance: Metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC) is lethal with no cure. This STTR Phase II project willdevelop a first-in-class Skp1 inhibitor that effectively targets mCRPC and conduct core battery toxicology andefficacy studies on GH501 as an advanced lead. Results collected from this project are essential to our futureInvestigational New Drug application to advance GH501 into clinical trials. We envision that GH501 representsa novel targeted therapy to improve the survival and quality of life of mCRPC patients. This highly innovativetranslational project could have a significant impact in reducing cancer mortality and morbidity.

Project Title: Children's Oncology Group NCI Community Oncology Research Program (NCORP) Research Base grant
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeThe Childrens Oncology Group (COG) is the worlds largest organization devoted exclusively to childhood andadolescent cancer research with more than 9000 members at over 220 leading childrens hospitals universitiesand cancer centers across the U.S. Canada and other countries. The COG conducts therapeutic trials as wellas cancer control and cancer care delivery research studies to improve outcomes across diverse populationsincluding adolescents and young adults with cancer.

Project Title: Using MOST to EMPOWER: Optimizing an Emotion Regulation Intervention to Enhance Well-being Among Young Adult Cancer Survivors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEYoung adult cancer survivors (YAs) experience many challenges that increase distress yet no supportive careinterventions exist for remote delivery to reduce distress and enhance well-being. Our main goal is to build offa pilot study of a multi-component web-based well-being intervention for YAs by collecting new data using anefficient research design to identify which intervention components work best. These data will guide futuretesting off the most effective (best) components of the intervention among YAs treated in community settings.
Study Section: Social Psychology, Personality and Interpersonal Processes Study Section[SPIP]

Project Title: Epigenomic and transcriptomic markers of aggressive prostate cancer among African American men
Public Health Relevance: Project narrative:The overall public health objective of this proposed study is to identify biomarkers that will improve risk-stratification for African American men with prostate cancer who bear a disproportionate burden of aggressivedisease and prostate cancer mortality but have been underrepresented in previous studies. This research inturn will allow for more personalized treatment/management strategies that have potential to improve patientoutcomes and reduce disparities in prostate cancer mortality.

Project Title: The Association Between CBT-I Dose Sleep Duration and Fatigue in Breast Cancer Patients
Public Health Relevance: Contact PD/PI: Perlis Michael (w/ Muench Alexandria)Project NarrativeThe data from the proposed study will allow for a more comprehensive understanding of the behavioralmechanisms that underlie insomnia and fatigue in breast cancer. It is proposed that high dose cognitivebehavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) will allow for larger magnitude increases in total sleep time (TST) andthat this alone or in combination with improved sleep continuity will diminish cancer-related fatigue (CRF).Improved sleep and/or decreased CRF holds the promise of providing breast cancer survivors with better qualityof life decreased stress and potentially improved immune functioning.

Project Title: Identifying Recurrent Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma in Electronic Health Data
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThis project seeks to develop the first electronic health record-based algorithms to identify patientsexperiencing recurrent non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL) in two large healthcare delivery systems with up to 21years of follow-up data. We will develop and evaluate both rule-based algorithms using structured EHR dataand data-driven algorithms using machine learning and natural language processing methods to analyze text-based documentation to identify recurrent NHL cases. Because recurrent cancers are not required to bereported to cancer registries we aim to develop innovative methods to efficiently and accurately identifyrecurrent NHL in electronic health data as the first step towards large-scale population-based analyses of thisimportant yet understudied patient outcome.
Organization Name: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER

Project Title: Improving Quality of Life of Prostate Cancer Survivors with Androgen Deficiency
Public Health Relevance: NarrativeThe South West Oncology Group (SWOG) and the SWOG Survivorship Committee havedeemed the treatment of the symptoms of testosterone deficiency in prostate cancer survivorsan important quality of life issue for prostate cancer survivors and a priority area for research.We propose to conduct the first double-blind placebo-controlled parallel-group randomizedtrial to determine whether testosterone replacement is safe and efficacious in improving themanifestations of androgen deficiency in men with organ-localized prostate cancer who haveundergone radical prostatectomy for pT2N0M0 Gleason score 6 disease and are at very lowrisk of disease recurrence.

Project Title: A Multilevel Approach to Cardiovascular Health in African American Breast Cancer Survivors: from Neighborhoods to Metabolomics
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEGiven the lowest prevalence of ideal cardiovascular health profiles in African American breast cancer survivorsand their excess mortality understanding the multilevel determinants of poor cardiovascular health isimperative to improve the breast cancer outcomes in this minority cancer population. The proposed study willidentify upstream neighborhood barriers to optimal cardiovascular health in African American breast cancersurvivors and downstream metabolomic signatures and mechanisms to breast cancer survival. The proposedstudy will provide translational insights into evidence-based neighborhood interventions and clinical strategieson metabolic alterations among African American breast cancer survivors to collectively reduce poor canceroutcomes in this understudied population.

Project Title: EXERCISING TOGETHER: A randomized controlled trial of partnered exercise training on the health of couples coping with cancer
Public Health Relevance: RelevanceOf the 14.5 million cancer survivors in the U.S. most are married. Cancer threatens quality of life and mortalityof survivors and their partners and strains their marriage. The proposed trial of partnered exercise training aimsto simultaneously improve physical mental and relationship health among married couples coping with cancer.

Project Title: SurvivorLink: Scalability of an Electronic Personal Health Record for Cancer Survivors and Caregivers at Pediatric Cancer Centers.
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativePrevious research suggests that children and adolescents with cancer are at heightened risk of late effects thatcan occur months or years after cancer treatment yet we still know little about programs that increase theirreturn for follow-up cancer care and late effects surveillance. This study will evaluate the impact of anelectronic personal health record and education system for pediatric cancer survivors and their caregivers. Thisstudy will provide the evidence base about the effects of the system to improve follow-up care for children andadolescents with cancer and best practices for implementation for pediatric cancer centers.
Study Section: Dissemination and Implementation Research in Health Study Section[DIRH]

Project Title: Optimizing functional recovery of breast cancer survivors
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEThe proposed research is relevant to public health because it tests a cancer rehabilitationintervention designed to increase breast cancer survivors' return to work school and valued lifeactivities. The individualized intervention promotes functional recovery from breast cancer byteaching survivors ways to adapt activities modify environments and enhance personalcapacity. This proposal reflects the National Cancer Institute Office of Cancer Survivorship'smission to reduce disability and improve the quality of life of cancer survivors.

Project Title: White Matter Toxicity and Neurocognitive Outcomes in Pediatric Brain Tumor Patients Treated with Proton Beam Radiation Therapy
Public Health Relevance: PROJECT NARRATIVEMany consider proton beam radiation therapy (PBRT) to be a promising treatment for children with braintumors as it may preserve cognitive functioning without sacrificing disease control. Currently there are nopublished studies assessing white matter toxicity and associated cognitive change in patients treated forpediatric brain tumors with PBRT. Ultimately this line of research is intended to: (1) help physicians andfamilies better understand the effect of PBRT on brain tissue and cognitive functioning to inform treatmentdecisions and (2) provide functional outcome data to be used toward justifying or reconciling the high cost andaccess limitations currently associated with PBRT.
Study Section: Behavioral Medicine, Interventions and Outcomes Study Section[BMIO]

Project Title: Web-based Physical Activity Intervention for Children with ALL
Public Health Relevance: REVELANCEThis project is designed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 24 week rewards-based physical activity interventiondelivered via an interactive website for children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) beginning just aftercompletion of curative chemotherapy on fitness biomarkers of cardiometabolic health physical activity qualityof life fatigue and school attendance. This proposal has relevance for public health as it will test the efficacy ofa portable cost-effective intervention designed to prevent/remediate known late effects of treatment amongchildren with ALL. This intervention will be tested using the infrastructure of the Children's Oncology Group toenroll children across multiple study sites. If successful it provides a model for not only children treated for ALLbut for other children whose acute disease and necessary treatments have late effects that interfere with futurehealth function and quality of life.

Project Title: Minority PDX Development and Trial Center: Baylor College of Medicine and MD Anderson Cancer Center Collaboration on Mechanistic Studies to Dissect and Combat Health Disparities in Cancer
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeOur multidisciplinary and multi-institutional collaborative team brings together experts in PDX model generationmolecular biology and signaling pathways animal drug treatment studies pathology and clinical managementof prostate and breast cancer from Baylor College of Medicine (BCM) and MD Anderson Cancer Center(MDACC) and is ideally positioned to leverage the technical resources of our institutions and our high numbersof racial and ethnic minority cancer patients at BCM in order to support the broader goals of the M-PDTC RFAin particular to facilitate biospecimen donations from these populations and increase the racial and ethnicdiversity of the PDXNet repository in a wide spectrum of cancers as well as to support the Specific Aims of ourtwo research projects in prostate and breast cancer. Few if any cancer centers have this combination of anoutstanding research base large numbers of African American Hispanic and Asian cancer patients and BCMsrobust track record of successfully enrolling minority patients from our catchment area (Houston) into clinicaltrials. Moreover our two research projects will utilize whole exome sequencing (WES) global RNA-sequencing(RNA-seq) quantitative proteomic (qKiP) and metabolomic profiling and will conduct preclinical trials ofpromising NCI-IND drugs to uncover novel effective treatment strategies for prostate and breast cancer inminority populations.

Project Title: Coordinating Center for Research Centers for Improving Management of Symptoms During and Following Cancer Treatment
Public Health Relevance: Project NarrativeMillions of cancer patients suffer from complications associated with their illness including symptoms that cansignificantly impact quality of life during treatment and survivorship. As the Coordinating Center for the newImproving Management of Symptoms Across Cancer Treatments (IMPACT) Consortium RTI International willfacilitate collaboration and coordination among the IMPACT Research Centers advancing efforts to improvesymptom control for cancer patients particularly those in minority and medically underserved populations.
